story:
Who is PPRWRK:

PPRWRK is the collaborative efforts of illustrator Mary Margaret LaVoie and photographer David Ruiz of 423BR.com. We combine our talents as PPRWRK to make wheat-paste murals, an affordable/removable alternative to paint. Our murals are a practice in impermanence, with a musically based influence, meant to make people smile by being a temporary change of scenery.

What We Need and Why:

After 2 years of amazing memories, we're ready to upgrade. Its time to purchase our own Océ PlotWave 300® Large Format Printer to make ourselves more available to the public. As visually explained in the video owning our own printer will not only cut down on production costs, but will cut out almost 40% of our labor hours. Our current method uses 11" x 17" sheets of paper that have to be individually hand cut, and then tiled up on the wall. The new method will decrease our cut, install, and removal time drastically just by upgrading to a 36" wide scroll print.

We are asking for $8000. 

  • $6500 - Océ PlotWave 300® Large Format Printer. These funds in addition to the $2500 we received from the 2012 MakeWork grant add up to the roughly $9000 we need to purchase and ship the new printer to us.
  • $1500 - Incentive costs such as: T-shirt printing, sticker production, 1 inch button production, hand sewn goods, mural costs (printing, paste, travel to installation) for the assortment of indoor/outdoor mural options, etc.

If additional funds past the $8000 are recieved, we plan to continue building PPRWRK to be a more affordable and repeatable option. Future expenses include, but are not limited to:

  • Funding local mural installs for schools or our community.
  • A supply of paper and toner for the printer.
  • Purchasing a second ladder to expedite installs.
  • Setting aside a bank used solely for design review fees and permit costs.
  • Building large surface cutting tables to make cutting our artwork a more controllable process.

What PPRWRK offers the community:

Our murals are all installed in public places meant to be enjoyed by everybody free of charge. Our murals also allow building/business owners a non-permanent alternative to a painted mural. We've pasted at schools, arts festivals, music festivals, in restaurants, for fun, and any other wall we've been allowed to.

PPRWRK 2012 Projects:

  • Red Bank High School - a Henry David Thoreau portait with the quote, "Go confidently in the direction of your dreams. Live the life you've imagined..." - (in conjunction with the schools 2012 revitilization efforts)
  • Normal Park Upper School - "Norm the Owl" (in conjunction with NORMALPALOOZA, an annual fund-raising event held by the school)
  • Gnarnia the Festival - a music festival in Beech Mountain North Carolina
  • The 10x10 showcase during HATCH Chattanooga Arts Week - we installed close to 2000 sq.ft. across Chattanooga
  • MainX24 - PPRWRK designed the festival t-shirt then installed the design at the corner of Main and Market St. We also installed the MainX24 logo, 480 sq.ft. total.
  • We have 3 consistently rotating walls in Chattanooga
  • We have indoor installs at 3 businesses in Chattanooga (working on a 4th at Community Pie)
  • We have murals in New York City, and in Austin TX.

Upcoming Projects:

Tour De Noog

In March of 2013, we will be launching our newest project “Tour De Noog”, an art assisted bike ride with an insistence on local art. This project is designed to promote community wellness by activating Chattanooga to get out and enjoy some free art and fresh air in our beautiful city. 

For our first showcase we plan to install up to 20 murals across downtown Chattanooga, from Frazier Avenue to Main Street, using David’s photographs to pay homage to some of Chattanooga’s local musicians. With 13 approved buildings, housing the 20 walls, and a pre-approval from the Chattanooga Sign Commission, this project is only gonna get bigger.

The project will launch with two showcases, the first on March 23rd, the second in June/July. Each showcase will hang for 30 days, then will be removed for 30-90 days in preparation for the next showcase. The second showcase will be of Mary’s illustration work, she plans to adorn the same walls with an imaginative and playful journey through Chattanooga.

Better Block Party

PPRWRK is currently working with Glass House Collective where we're installing a series of murals for the Better Block party on February 23rd. Mary's designs for this project are geared towards to youth of the area, exciting them to enjoy their community, and to want to make it better for and by themselves. She has critters performing different maintainance tasks, amongst an array of beautifying illustrations throughout the city block.

Cyclopaedia

We are also about to install our hype murals for Cyclopaedia, a project by Chattanooga local artist Tim Hinck, with showtimes February 21st - 25th. Tim is a fellow 2012 MakeWork Grant recipient, and has hired us to assist in advertising his upcoming project. Cyclopaedia will be bringing many forms of art together: dancers, singers, musicians, videographers, photographers, actors, he's pretty much got it covered.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you don't have the means to donate the cash, you can still do your part:

  • Share this campaign on your Facebook page.
  • Tweet this campaign on your Twitter.
  • Tell the family philanthropist how AWESOME of a project this will be.
  • Anything and everything to get the HYPE out.

Regardless, thank you for your time, and please TELL EVERYBODY!!!

Special Thanks to:

  • Joel Ruiz of Evatt and Bloom for handling all the pre and post production of the campaign video.
  • SoCro for the music used in the campaign video.
  • MakeWork for starting PPRWRK on the prosperous track that we're glidin' on today.
  • ... and everybody who has believed in us, thanked us, or just smiled at our art...

THANK YOU ALL!!!

Now get ready.

story:
This campaign is raising funds for the festival that directs all of its' non-expenses to Art 180 that will fund arts education for one of RVA's most recognized and beloved non-profts.

The RVA Street Art Festival is defined by three things - supporting arts education for children, discovering and showcasing local artistic talent alongside big national artists, and revitalizing challenged areas that are in dire need of some color and creativity.

This year the festival will return to Richmond in September to revitalize 5.5 acres of walls and buildings on the former GRTC depot on Cary St. with public art, murals sessions, sculpture, and exhibits and ideas about the history and future of transportation in Richmond.

Nationally and internationally acclaimed artists will join with local talent to create murals on the trolley barns, create sculpture using materials on site, and focusing on expanding the conversation about transportation options and potential in Richmond.

You can help make this event possible and exceed expectations by being one of the first to get a limited edition T-shirt, poster, sunglasses, mural print, or spray paint can to help fund the festival in addition to support from our sponsors. All the post-expense proceeds benefit Art 180 that creates and provides art-related programs for young people living in challenging circumstances, encouraging personal and community change through self-expression.

The festival will showcase the creative power of street art, liven up the drab walls and attract people to the outdoor art gallery as well as spark a creative discussion about transportation. Spectators will watch large murals and sculptures come to life and color and creativity explode on site all while being able to interact with the artists.

The festival will feature public art and sculpture sessions Wednesday, September 11 through Sunday, September 15, and incorporate painting, sculpture as well as projects in collaboration with the University of Richmond.

An artist forum will be held at the Byrd Theatre on Thursday, September 12 where artists will discuss the street art movement growing from a behind the scenes movement to becoming a commercially viable and sought after medium in many venues from clothes to cars to corporate boardrooms.

A "Paint the Walls" pre-party will take place on Wednesday, August 21 where attendees can tour the site pre-festival, and take part in creating a collaborative mural. The pre-party will also host a contest to find the next generation of up and coming local muralists in RVA. 20 artists will get a chance to create their own 6x6 murals and be juried by the artists invited to the festival in September. The top selected artists will be given their own large mural space they can paint during the festival. Click here for more details. 

Invited artists include Jeff Soto, El Kamino, Pablo Harymbat, Hamilton Glass, the Few and Far Women crew, Pose, Omens, Vizie, Andrew Schoultz, Hense, Jessie Unterhalter and Katie Truhn, Joshua Mays, Mike Broth, Brad Bacon, Rich Colman, Matt Betts, Chris Milk Hulburt, Heidi Trepanier, Tyler Thomas, Adam Juresko, Camera Obscura, Nikki Leone, Josh van Horne, Marshall Higgins, and more. These artists will work side by side with more than a dozen local artists and muralists to inject color and creativity to the seldom used and static GRTC property.

Local and national sculptors will create pieces from materials found on site (including parts from old buses) as well as showcase sound installations using current GRTC buses. The GRTC site is the original site of the Richmond City Railway Company and served as a transit hub for more than 100 years.

A multimedia exhibition entitled “Keep on Rolling: Stories and Portraits of GRTC Operators” will include photographic portraits of GRTC drivers, text panels based on interviews, and sound portraits. City buses have played a major part at watershed moments in Richmond history, such as the civil rights movement and changes in neighborhoods caused by urban renewal. GRTC operators continue to see and experience a side of life in Richmond that most people do not—but their stories have largely gone untold.

The transportation theme will include a focus on both two and four wheels. Beyond the car, there will be exhibits focused on existing transit options as well as potential solutions such as Bus Rapid Transit and the possibility of creating a regional transit system.

Bicyles will also be prominent during the festival. An urban bike skills obstacle course used to train the Richmond Police will be set up for people to use and will remain on the property in future similar to the trails obstacle course on Belle Isle. Ride Richmond will host Bike Polo matches and there will also be ramps for stunts and tricks. Richmond 2015 will also be on hand to promote the 2015 UCI World Championships and promote their legacy projects underway througout the region that promote cycling.

The festival will include a RVA Street Art Satellite Gallery (on site) featuring works from participating artists, local food trucks from RVA Street Foodies, drink from the Taste the Local campaign, Virginia wine, artists and crafts from the Bizarre Market, arts activities for children, plus artist work sessions and public interaction.

The proceeds from the festival will once again benefit Art 180 which will gather children invovled in their programs around Richmond to create incredible murals during the festival. 

Following last year’s successful RVA Street Art Festival, co-organizers Ed Trask and Jon Baliles have teamed up with artist and curator Vaughn Garland, who co-organized the acclaimed Manchester Sculpture Invitational in 2005-06. Together, the trio has worked with GRTC to plan the festival and transform the site until the property is sold or developed, sometime in 2016.

Visit us for updates and artist profiles on the web and social media at http://www.rvastreetart.com

story:
A ‘Choose your own adventure’ blog starring yours truly.

At a three week long Pilchuck workshop this July, I will keep an online journal about the adventures, misadventures, fortunes won, loves lost (and all the juicy gossip) so that you will have an intimate understanding of what it is I, and other artists do at these retreats and why it’s so important to go.  Not only will I make this a fun, real-life novella that is written as it is experienced, but you will influence the narrative by giving me brainstorming ideas for artwork.  Since I am going to this workshop to be challenged and grow as an artist, I will use each of your suggestions like assignments on some secret mission.  Like a good improv show, I’ll figure out a way to focus on every one of your ideas at some point during the retreat!  Not only will this be a fun and informative blog to follow, but you will take pride when you read the chapter that you helped to create because of the idea you put in my head.  It’s like a ‘Choose your own adventure’ book where each person gets to suggest one chapter and I, the protagonist, will tie it together into a cohesive whole.  You, my supporters, are not just helping me to attend this summer art camp, you are my fellow collaborators in a project whose purpose is to develop a visual language we can all understand.  No matter how far flung you may be, everyone can participate in this particular project and together we will make art happen!

 

What you are for me:

You are my public, my base; you are the folks I want to connect with.  I want to know how you think about art and how I might be able to make artwork that can be understood and appreciated by YOU.  Have you ever had the experience of going to a museum or gallery, wandering around and thinking “Am I the only one here who doesn’t get it?”  I have that feeling often, and it seems like the Art World isn’t concerned so much with whether or not people “get it.”  Personally, I feel it extremely important to be able to communicate my ideas through art in a way that can be understood by as many people as possible.  That’s why I’ve started this project which will involve your thoughts and ideas about what art could be.  I want to hear your stories of when you’ve been moved by art, or ideas you’ve always thought would make a cool show, or even your personal philosophy of what you call art and what you don’t.  With a survey of your opinions I will be able to start developing symbols of universal meaning that can express our modern day experience through sculpture and installation.

Here are some examples of what I’ve got so far from your suggestions:

  • A theme called Paradox where two opposites show a deep truth of reality.
  • Visually, something that looks like one thing from far away and another from close up.
  • Badgers! –why not?

 

What I am for you:

The focus of my work increasingly has to do with communities and the roles we play in society.  By getting you all involved in sending me to Pilchuck I’m making the class into its own community project.  I want you to know about, and then to have a part in, what it is I do.  I want you to have good art in your lives and feel proud that you are part of the inspiration for it.  Rather than a solo journey for me to the mountain top, I’m going to bring you along on the journey and share what I learn.  To keep it an interactive process, I will be updating every day and remain available via e-mail for questions and comments.  I want this experience to be an open dialogue with you because the more people who share their opinions the better I’ll be at creating an understandable visual language for my art.  As an added bonus, after such intensive training and inspiration I will be all jazzed up to return to my studio and create new sculptures.  I can’t think of more deserving people to be the recipients of such creative outpouring than those who made it possible.  You are the people I can rely upon for encouragement, honest opinions, and support, and I want each of you to have something of mine that means something to you.

So give what you can, if you can.  I appreciate it all, but if you can’t, the most important thing to me is having you aboard.  Anyone can send me an idea and come along with me on this journey!

story:
Short Summary

"For me, artistic activity is a spiritual activity that all artists practice." – Robert Filliou, artist

My name is Raghubir and I am a teaching artist and a teaching Kundalini yogi.  

I have a multi-disciplinary practice through which I am always exploring the confluence of artistic and spiritual practices. In all my different kinds of projects (which include studio art and/or social practice, pedagogy, and in yoga classes and workshops)  I emphasize that with yogic technology at its core, creativity and art-making have the potential to transform individual and group consciousness and to ultimately change the world...whether you consider yourself an artist or not.

"Creativity is not just for artists. It's for businesspeople looking for a new way to close a sale; it's for engineers trying to solve a problem; it's for parents who want their children to see the world in more than one way." - Twyla Tharp, dancer and choreographer

I've been "writing" The Eleven Yogic Arts of Creative Living for many years. It's gone through multiple iterations and it's content has found it's way into the classes and workshops I teach both as an art teacher and a yoga instructor/trainer. Yogic technology informs everything I do both in and out of the art studio.  Since yogic technology is such a valuable tool for transformation and creativity, I feel it is essential to include yogic curriculum in schools, workplaces, and institutions.  This book takes the position that everyone is creative, and that your power, influence, and happiness is ultimately dependent on how you access and manage this natural energy flow.  

I practice Kundalini Yoga and the Teachings of Yogi Bhajan. For those not familiar with Yogi Bhajan or his teachings,  he arrived in Los Angeles virtually unknown in 1968 and shared the secret teachings of Kundalini Yoga with young spiritual seekers of the era.  He immediately recognized that the experience of higher consciousness they were attempting to find through drugs, could be achieved by practicing the Science of Kundalini Yoga, while simultaneously rebuilding their nervous systems. Breaking the centuries old tradition of secrecy surrounding the empowering science of Kundalini Yoga, he began teaching it publicly. With yogic technology of meditation, physical exercises and postures, yogic philosophy, and loving acceptance, he gave an effective alternative to a self-destructive and non-productive way of life. Inspired and motivated by Yogi Bhajan's words and adhering to the practices he taught, his students got creative! Tons of music, art, poetry and creative businesses flowed forth; reflecting the connection to the Universal flow of consciousness he shared with everyone. In addition to writing and speaking extensively about Creativity, Yogi Bhajan's expertise and influence affected people in all fields and from all walks of life; in the healing arts, the business world, in the arts, religion, government and sports. You could say that he embodied a rare combination of spiritual and down-to-earth practical wisdom which anyone can apply to any aspect of life.  

Although I had been a yoga and meditation practitioner for most of my adult life, when I started practicing these teachings in the mid-2000's, my life seriously transformed for the better. I wasn't planning to teach the stuff, I just wanted to deepen my practice. When I started teaching in order to be of service to others, that's when everything in my life really shifted. Delving into the lectures of Yogi Bhajan, I found tremendous amounts of information about creativity - what it is, how to get it, how to maintain it, and how to share it in such a way that you never are without it.  This found its way into my blogs, newsletters, and classes. As you can imagine, it was suggested to me over and over again that a book was around the corner. That's the story.

If I was going to write a book, I wanted to create a tool that gave people access to their creativity no matter what they did; no matter their creative track record.  I wanted the book to be both useful and empowering. Being an advocate for safe self-expression and creative empowerment, I wanted it to be user-friendly and beneficial for artists, spiritual seekers and practitioners, students, teachers. I envisioned a resource that would give readers a better understanding of HOW creativity works so that they could access, manage and deliver it with impact in any way they chose.  

    What I Need & What you Get

    I decided to self publish through Kindle Direct Publishing (KDP). In the quest for my book's completion and distribution, I realized that I needed financial help. That's when Indiegogo came to mind. I found an editor and a self-publishing guru who could hold my hand and guide me through the process. Not only is she a great cheerleader, she's a marketing and social media wiz who will help me intelligently and productively place my book in the right hands.​

    • Your contributions will help me to get it formatted, printed and distributed by a pro.
    • In today's publishing world, one needs certain media tools and these cost money, too.
    • I have done all the ground work - basically wrote the content of the book - but now I need some fuel to get my book off the ground!
    • HELP!

    What do I need?  $5,000. At least that...but my goal is officially $5,650 (this covers the Indiegogo fees and their holding fund). 

    Years of writing, teaching, self-experimentation, research and practice have gone into this project.  I've taught the material in various formats including art-based workshops, panel discussions, lectures and in a series format. Some of the material is broadcasted on RAMA TV as part of my class series on creativity. Much of my draft was written from workshop and class notes as well as from copious research notes from my MFA thesis and transcriptions of Yogi Bhajan's lectures.

    What does the $5,650 cover?

    • Just about all the marketing costs........................................$3000
    • Content formatting and editing.............................................$1500
    • Printing (100 to start) 7 x 10" books @ $5  ............................$500
    • Holding amount and Indiegogo processing fees....................$650
    • What if I don't meet my goal? Well, whatever funds I do get, will go to my publishing team and the printing of less books.

    What do you get? Aside from the various incentives available to contributors, you'll get the satisfaction that comes with helping to produce and broadcast a valuable and practical tool for the artistic and yogic community.  

    The impact your contribution will have

    • I not only want to get this book into the hands of artists and yogis, but I'd love to get this book into high schools, colleges and art institutions. It should be recommended reading for students in art schools and required reading for any art or yoga teacher.
    • Yogi Bhajan said that the purpose of creativity is to create an impact. By filtering The Teachings of Yogi Bhajan through the lens of Creativity, I feel that this book will change the way we teach art in schools, make art in our studios and how we share art with the world. 
    • So many people I have taught and/or counseled have deep insecurities regarding their own creative contributions, abilities or projects. Hopefully this book will empower and inspire.
    • Finding the purpose, meaning and creative potential in my own yogic practice has had a profound effect on me and I hope that the book will spark a similar experience and realization in others.

    Risks & Challenges

    • My only challenges are time and money...but I have set it up so that my realistic goals for the publication of The Eleven Yogic Arts of Creative Living can be reached.
    • My time goal is to get it out into the world, by the very latest, January 1, 2020. It will require lots of scheduling and discipline - both of which I do well.
    • I believe that my money goal of $5000 can be met through your generous donations by the end of the summer.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Maybe you can't contribute financially. That doesn't mean that you can't help:

    • Get the word out on social media! Repost, share, and share again!
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • If you've been to my Creativity Classes or Workshops (or have watched them on RAMA TV) and have had a good experience, tell people about it and link to this campaign.  Thanks!
story_txt:
Short Summary
"For me, artistic activity is a spiritual activity that all artists practice." – Robert Filliou, artist
My name is Raghubir and I am a teaching artist and a teaching Kundalini yogi.  
I have a multi-disciplinary practice through which I am always exploring the confluence of artistic and spiritual practices. In all my different kinds of projects (which include studio art and/or social practice, pedagogy, and in yoga classes and workshops)  I emphasize that with yogic technology at its core, creativity and art-making have the potential to transform individual and group consciousness and to ultimately change the world...whether you consider yourself an artist or not.
"Creativity is not just for artists. It's for businesspeople looking for a new way to close a sale; it's for engineers trying to solve a problem; it's for parents who want their children to see the world in more than one way." - Twyla Tharp, dancer and choreographer
I've been "writing" The Eleven Yogic Arts of Creative Living for many years. It's gone through multiple iterations and it's content has found it's way into the classes and workshops I teach both as an art teacher and a yoga instructor/trainer. Yogic technology informs everything I do both in and out of the art studio.  Since yogic technology is such a valuable tool for transformation and creativity, I feel it is essential to include yogic curriculum in schools, workplaces, and institutions.  This book takes the position that everyone is creative, and that your power, influence, and happiness is ultimately dependent on how you access and manage this natural energy flow.  
I practice Kundalini Yoga and the Teachings of Yogi Bhajan. For those not familiar with Yogi Bhajan or his teachings,  he arrived in Los Angeles virtually unknown in 1968 and shared the secret teachings of Kundalini Yoga with young spiritual seekers of the era.  He immediately recognized that the experience of higher consciousness they were attempting to find through drugs, could be achieved by practicing the Science of Kundalini Yoga, while simultaneously rebuilding their nervous systems. Breaking the centuries old tradition of secrecy surrounding the empowering science of Kundalini Yoga, he began teaching it publicly. With yogic technology of meditation, physical exercises and postures, yogic philosophy, and loving acceptance, he gave an effective alternative to a self-destructive and non-productive way of life. Inspired and motivated by Yogi Bhajan's words and adhering to the practices he taught, his students got creative! Tons of music, art, poetry and creative businesses flowed forth; reflecting the connection to the Universal flow of consciousness he shared with everyone. In addition to writing and speaking extensively about Creativity, Yogi Bhajan's expertise and influence affected people in all fields and from all walks of life; in the healing arts, the business world, in the arts, religion, government and sports. You could say that he embodied a rare combination of spiritual and down-to-earth practical wisdom which anyone can apply to any aspect of life.

I wasn't planning to teach the stuff, I just wanted to deepen my practice. When I started teaching in order to be of service to others, that's when everything in my life really shifted. Delving into the lectures of Yogi Bhajan, I found tremendous amounts of information about creativity - what it is, how to get it, how to maintain it, and how to share it in such a way that you never are without it.  This found its way into my blogs, newsletters, and classes. As you can imagine, it was suggested to me over and over again that a book was around the corner. That's the story.
If I was going to write a book, I wanted to create a tool that gave people access to their creativity no matter what they did; no matter their creative track record.  I wanted the book to be both useful and empowering. Being an advocate for safe self-expression and creative empowerment, I wanted it to be user-friendly and beneficial for artists, spiritual seekers and practitioners, students, teachers. I envisioned a resource that would give readers a better understanding of HOW creativity works so that they could access, manage and deliver it with impact in any way they chose.  


What I Need & What you Get
I decided to self publish through Kindle Direct Publishing (KDP). In the quest for my book's completion and distribution, I realized that I needed financial help. That's when Indiegogo came to mind. I found an editor and a self-publishing guru who could hold my hand and guide me through the process. Not only is she a great cheerleader, she's a marketing and social media wiz who will help me intelligently and productively place my book in the right hands.​

Your contributions will help me to get it formatted, printed and distributed by a pro.
In today's publishing world, one needs certain media tools and these cost money, too.
I have done all the ground work - basically wrote the content of the book - but now I need some fuel to get my book off the ground!
HELP!

What do I need?  $5,000. At least that...but my goal is officially $5,650 (this covers the Indiegogo fees and their holding fund). 
Years of writing, teaching, self-experimentation, research and practice have gone into this project.  I've taught the material in various formats including art-based workshops, panel discussions, lectures and in a series format. Some of the material is broadcasted on RAMA TV as part of my class series on creativity. Much of my draft was written from workshop and class notes as well as from copious research notes from my MFA thesis and transcriptions of Yogi Bhajan's lectures.
What does the $5,650 cover?

Just about all the marketing costs........................................$3000
Content formatting and editing.............................................$1500
Printing (100 to start) 7 x 10" books @ $5  ............................$500
Holding amount and Indiegogo processing fees....................$650
What if I don't meet my goal? Well, whatever funds I do get, will go to my publishing team and the printing of less books.

What do you get? Aside from the various incentives available to contributors, you'll get the satisfaction that comes with helping to produce and broadcast a valuable and practical tool for the artistic and yogic community.  

The impact your contribution will have

I not only want to get this book into the hands of artists and yogis, but I'd love to get this book into high schools, colleges and art institutions. It should be recommended reading for students in art schools and required reading for any art or yoga teacher.
Yogi Bhajan said that the purpose of creativity is to create an impact. By filtering The Teachings of Yogi Bhajan through the lens of Creativity, I feel that this book will change the way we teach art in schools, make art in our studios and how we share art with the world. 
So many people I have taught and/or counseled have deep insecurities regarding their own creative contributions, abilities or projects. Hopefully this book will empower and inspire.
Finding the purpose, meaning and creative potential in my own yogic practice has had a profound effect on me and I hope that the book will spark a similar experience and realization in others.


Risks & Challenges

My only challenges are time and money...but I have set it up so that my realistic goals for the publication of The Eleven Yogic Arts of Creative Living can be reached.
My time goal is to get it out into the world, by the very latest, January 1, 2020. It will require lots of scheduling and discipline - both of which I do well.
I believe that my money goal of $5000 can be met through your generous donations by the end of the summer.


Other Ways You Can Help
Maybe you can't contribute financially. That doesn't mean that you can't help:

Get the word out on social media! Repost, share, and share again!
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
If you've been to my Creativity Classes or Workshops (or have watched them on RAMA TV) and have had a good experience, tell people about it and link to this campaign.  Thanks!

story:
A Treasure for the Community

The Irish Sculpture Park is about breathing life into an Irish folktale written in the 7th century "the Voyage of Máel Dúin - the Devotee of God". The park will comprise of 1,500 sculptures spread over 33 locations. At each location a group of sculptures will depict an episode of the folktale. The sculptures will be placed along a walkway of four-to-five miles in Killarney town. 

THIS fundraising campaign is about SECURING SEED-CAPITAL to design the park and to begin the first phase of development. YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS will guarantee that this venture will become a thriving success and together we can create a piece of HISTORICAL ART that can be APPRECIATED for the next 1,000 YEARS. 

I believe that this sculpture park will be an INSPIRATION in terms of CREATIVITY, and as a walkway it will promote a sense WELL-BEING and OUTDOOR ACTIVITY.

I am hoping that 15,000 people from Ireland, Europe, and the United States will each DONATE € 22 to ensure the fundraising target is 100% fulfilled. 


"The Oak sleeps in the Acorn. The Bird waits in the Egg, and in the highest vision of the Soul, a waking Angel stirs. DREAMS ARE THE SEEDLINGS OF REALITY.


How your Money will be Invested

  • The launch of the sculpture park and the ILLUSTRATION of DETAILED SKETCHES of the 1,500 SCULPTURES, so people can envisage the full magnitude of the park. 
  • The SUCCESSFUL CREATION of TEN NEW JOBS within the first year of the project being up and running.
  • The commission of the first segment of the sculpture park - an impressive ARCHWAY cast in bronze comprising of TWO TOWERING PILLARS, each with THREE EAGLES perched on top - the Gateway to the Voyage. 
  • The SECUREMENT of Job Creation Grants in Ireland potentially worth € 150,000. 
  • The DEVELOPMENT of an INTERACTIVE WEBSITE for you to follow the project.

OUR GOAL

Securing SEED-CAPITAL for this project will set the momentum for our campaign, and how we can deliver on timelines with regards the construction of the park

  • In the first year we hope to raise € 750,000, create 10 new jobs and put in place the entire framework for the project. 
  • By the end of YEAR TWO, with your help, we will have 20 full-time employees. We will have raised € 2 million in cash, and we'll be in a position to expand in proportion to our fundraising successes.
  • WE WILL HAVE PUT UP THE FIRST 33 SCULPTURES, one at each of the primary locations along the walkway. People will now be able to appreciate the full magnitude of the venture, and as we enter YEAR THREE we will expand accordingly, enriching each of the locations with additional sculptures.

For full details of the descriptive nature of the sculptures in the park - scroll downwards, BUT FIRST

Be Creative and Supportive

WE NEED YOUR HELP TO MAKE THIS PROJECT A SUCCESS

  • Be GENEROUS and CONTRIBUTE. Whether its € 1, € 10 or a € 100. 
  • Take a look at our PERKS, ASK YOURSELF, WHICH ONE WOULD YOU LIKE?
  • Which PERK would a FRIEND or a FAMILY MEMBER like?
  • SHARE the ABOVE LINK on FACEBOOK, TWITTER and GOOGLE.
  • ADD a COMMENT, tell us what you LIKE. This is very IMPORTANT.
  • (Every time you SHARE a Link or make a comment on this CAMPAIGN you help promote this page to the NUMBER ONE SPOT on INDIEGOGO.COM, who in turn advertise us as the number one project to support. We are competing against 5,000 other projects. Let the IRISH SCULPTURE PARK be the one that succeeds most. MAKE US PART OF YOUR TEAM).

A Few More IMPORTANT FACTS

  • The Sculpture Park will cost in its lifetime an estimated € 75 million to build, which will be a massive boost to the economy in Killarney and the South of Ireland.
  • 150 highly skilled jobs will be created during the 10 years of its construction.
  • The first two years of the project are about getting the venture off the ground and putting in place the first 33 PRIMARY SCULPTURES so people can start enjoying the walkway and are able to visualize what they will continue to contribute their money towards.
  • Upon full completion of the park we'll have directly created an additionally 30 jobs in Killarney, associated with the management, maintenance and security of the project.
  • Further to that we will have indirectly helped to create and sustain a further 120 jobs in Killarney, associated with hotels, restaurants, tourism, travel, amenities etc.
  • The project will be worth an estimated € 7 million to the local economy in Killarney on an annual basis, and WILL ATTRACT between 250,000 to 350,000 VISITORS annually. 
  • If we are successful in raising the SEED CAPITAL we can apply for upwards of € 2.3 million in Job Creation Grants, over the ten years of the construction of the park.
  • Upwards of € 15 million of the project is likely to be raised through Government Grants associated with Tourism, the Development of Walkways, the Funding of Artistic Projects, and Job Creation.
  • The remaining € 60 million will be raised through corporate sponsorship, as well as a variety of fundraising activities, especially amongst the Irish Diaspora across the globe. There are 1.2 million people who visit Killarney annually, hopefully each of them will give us on average € 5 each year. Result € 60 million to complete our project.
  • This Sculpture Park will be the only park of its kind in the world and will pave the way for us to develop similar projects in Ireland based on Irish legends such as: the Children of Lír, Cú Chulainn, Queen Maeve, Fionn Mac Cumhaill & the Fianna, Deirdre of the Sorrows, and Oisín in Tír na nÓg. 
  • The reason the Voyage of Máel Dúin has been chosen ahead of other Irish folktales is because of its hugely descriptive nature, and its progression in 33 defined pieces of literature. This affords the designers of the park the opportunity to create great contrast along the walkway so the sculptures can be appreciated to their full craftsmanship.

€ 22 is what we need you to donate!

If you have a Creative Spirit, if you are Artistic, if you have vivid imagination, if you love idealistic dreams, if you love to see living treasures then PLEASE generously support this incredibly ambitious project. 

If 15,000 of us each give € 22 our FUNDRAISING TARGET will be reached.

Can you afford € 22 and help create 150 new jobs??? SAY YES YOU CAN

(Thank you for reading this far. If you would like a copy of the Voyage of Máel Dúin which describes the sculpture park, then please send me your email to  irishsculpturepark@yahoo.ie   and I'll forward you a copy of the folktale").

Who is Máel Dúin?

And what is the sculpture park to be about?

Máel Dúin is a Heroic figure in Irish literature who most likely lived around the 5th or 6th century. His father was a king of the Eoghanacht of Munster and his mother was a Nun. The day before Máel Dúin was born his father was murdered by plunderers from an offshore island. Máel Dúin's mother gave up her son to fosterage and in his late teens he finally discovers his true parentage and sets off on a voyage to revenge his father's death. Twenty warriors accompany Máel Dúin on the voyage, but on the first night they are blown off course by a mystical wind into the realms of another world. For several years they seek passage back to Ireland and encounter 33 strange islands upon their voyage. The Irish sculpture park is about recreating the settings of each of the 33 islands and the strange things Máel Dúin and his companions uncover. The story is said to be a subliminal account of Irelands conversion to Christianity, and relates how he sets off on a passage of vengeance but returns with a heart of forgiveness. 

The thirty-three islands mentioned in the Voyage of Máel Dúin that will be recreated in the Irish Sculpture Park:


1. the Island of Giant Ants;   2. the Island Covered in Birds 

3. the Island of the Hound-footed Horses;   4. the Island of Invisible Riders

5. the Island Abundant in Salmon;   6. the Island of Trees

7. the Island of the Revolving Beast;   8. the Island of Cannibal Horses

9. the Island of Fiery Pigs;   10. the Island of Cats;  11. the Island of Black & White

12. the Island of Giant Cattle;   13. the Island of the Mill;   14. the Island of Sorrow

15. the Island of the Four Fences;   16. the Island of the Crystal Keep

17. the Island of Singing Birds;   18. the Island of Ancestors

19. the Island of the Hermit;   20. the Island of the Forge

21. the Island of the Sea of Glass;   22. the Island of the Sea of Mist

23. the Island of Recognition;   24. the Island of the Rainbow Stream

25. the Island of the Silver Net;   26. the Island of the Shuttered Door

27. the Island of Women;   28. the Island of Berries;   29. the Island of the Eagle

30. the Island of Joy;    31. the Island of Circled Fire;   32. the Island of Otters

33. the Island of the Falcon

story:
Our Story

Art Relief International (ARI) works to transform the lives of struggling social groups in Northern Thailand by offering them the opportunity to express themselves through an artistic lens.

Art changes lives. It is both a powerful means of expression and a recognized means of therapy – two things our participants badly need in their lives. ARI works to cultivate creativity, creating an atmosphere of inclusion for groups that are often cast out and ignored, and encourage social change.

ARI has recently launched an exciting project – The Young Lions Global Art Project. This project reaches out to children living in the neighborhood around our office in Chiang Mai, Thailand. Many of the children who attend are Burmese or hill tribe.  Their families are extremely poor and have moved to Chiang Mai with the hopes of making more money.

After school, these children walk the streets selling strings of jasmine flowers to help support their families and put food on the table. With so much time spent trying to survive, these children have little time left to be kids.


The Impact

The Young Lions Global Art Project gives these children space and time to express themselves creatively and to be children. Each week the children are introduced to a different country and culture from around the World, learning special things about that country and partaking in a creative project inspired by it’s culture. Some of the past projects have included, Tanzanian war shields, batik scarves, woven notebook covers, tie-dyed bandannas, Jackson Pollack style t-shirts, and Chinese style watercolor paintings. 

Through art we have been able to reach out to the families and children in the neighborhood and build a rapport, which allows us to give the children a chance of, not only self-expression, but also to play, build friendships, and develop positive relationships between Thai and Burmese minority groups.


What We Need

The Young Lions Global Art Project has been such a tremendous success that we would love to expand and reach out to those groups who do not have the opportunity to come to us – Those living in Chiang Mai’s many construction camp slums. 


In Chiang Mai there are approximately 120,000 Burmese refugees and migrants. They come in the search for freedom from fear, oppression, military brutality and violations of their human rights. The reality of what they face here is a lot different. Jobs for Burmese migrant workers are limited and many work on large construction projects for small amounts of money. These workers are utilized for cheap labor, but are not given rights or residency by the Thai government. As a result, they have no choice but to live in ramshackle accommodations on the labor camps. Without residency rights, the children cannot attend school and often help on site during the day. 

We believe we can use art as a tool to build a relationship with this community and a means to provide educational and creative opportunities for these children. The Young Lions Global Art Project would love the opportunity to partner with a local construction camps to implement a 12 week art curriculum in which the kids learn a variety of skills and techniques including painting, pattern design, drawing, crafts, 3D art, and textile work. The project will also incorporate useful items such as clothing and school supplies and provide a small snack. 

Our project has two main benefits:

  1. Provide an artistic release for children living in extreme poverty

  2. Raise awareness and break down social prejudices against Burmese minorities in Thailand.


How You Can Help?

A little goes a long way - We've worked out that if every member of our facebook fan page, causes page, and myspace donated $5 each, we would be very close to reaching our fund-raising goal!


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the Word - Tell all of your friends!

Share this campaign - post it on your blog facebook page, myspace, twitter etc..

story:
Our Story

The good news: our book is already published in Greece by Kastaniotis editions, December 2010.

The better news we hope for: with your help, to publish it internationally!

We started this journey to reveal the social identity of the modern Muslim society of Western Thrace. On our own initiative and taking advantage of our being women, we dared to get into a completely sealed world and earn the trust of this minority, in order to know it better.

With great patience and persistence and our journalistic experience about the Muslim culture as our great asset, over two years (2008-2010), we were accepted into the homes of the Muslims and became part of their lives. We lived with them; we shared their troubles and their dreams. We became familiar with the contradictory reality of three minorities: Pomaks, Turkish, Roma. But we also discovered one small minority, unknown until then: the Sudanese, whose ancestors came to Thrace as slaves during the Ottoman Dominion.

We photographed the modern Muslim woman in private family moments, the young people at school and during their free time, the work -a work in decline- in the tobacco fields. We got permission from the Ministry of Education to enter minority schools. There, we became familiar with the critical problems in education â€“ a source of major problems in this society. We listened to the Muslim Greek citizens confiding to us the crucial  issues they have to deal with within their sociopolitical life.

Since the mid 1990's we both have been covering stories, for Greek magazines and newspapers, addressing major social problems and situations modern society faces, both in Greece and abroad. Guided by a shared sensibility and interest, we have achieved a productive cooperation with social and political content.

www.elenamoschidi.com

www.pepiloulakaki.com


The Impact

Through this photographic edition, based on journalistic research, we aim to present to the rest of the world the unknown world of Greek Thrace â€“ a beautiful part of Greece that has mostly met with ignorance and indifference.

Besides the sociopolitical problems that Muslims in Thrace face, they have a huge and rich cultural heritage which needs to be protected and become known more widely, so it doesn't fade away.

Our goal is that this book not to be limited within the Greek borders, but translated and published internationally.

We have already  contacted with publishers in Europe and Turkey, who have showed great interest in our book but  the costs for translation and printing need to be covered first.

Universities around the world dealing with minority issues and Islam have also shown great interest in our book. We have been invited to lecture on it and introduce it to their students -another reason (and audience) for which translation and publication of this work is needed.


What We Need & What You Get

We need:  Translation into English and Turkish in a single edition, plus the Printing Costs, amounting to a total of:   24.000$

You can help by donating and get several perks.

You get: Look at the perks!!


Spread the word, use your Facebook page and email contacts to help share it, recommend this project to friends, associates and organizations and send them the link to our Indiegogo campaign page. Stay in touch with us, "Like" & follow our Facebook Page http://www.facebook.com/THRACEBOOK and keep up to date with the behind the scenes production events. Contact us on our emails: pepiloulakaki@gmail.com and info@elenamoschidi.com. We want and appreciate your feedback so all comments are welcome!!


In case we do not reach our goal, if the amount raised allows, we will proceed with an English only translation, with the rest of the money being donated to the homeless people of Athens.

If we exceed our goal, we will still donate the excess money to the homeless people of Athens www.cityofathens.gr/en/node/7511 and www.kyada.gr.

story:
Whoops!

We're currently re-building our website, adding all of our new designs and products and making the site easier to use all around.  Unfortunately, many of the links at the right reference the old site.  In order to keep us from changing promised perks after you've contributed, Indiegogo doesn't allow us to edit these areas.  But you can visit http://curiouscustoms.com/  and get a look at a partial selection of what we have to offer. We're  photographing all of our new line and will be getting it up in the next week. Thanks for your understanding; we wear many hats around here!

Our Story

Hi.  We're Dave and Marrilee and we are artists who like to create and share interactive art. 


The Impact

Previously, most of our interactive art was temporary in nature, being shared with our community and then let go; up, up in flames.  The art we're now making though centers around a different kind of interactivity: creating platforms that can be shared and re-shared. We want to create a performance stage for the 8th annual Art Outside festival (http://www.artoutside.org) that professional performers, casual entertainers, and those new to sharing their gifts and finding their voice can enjoy an audience from. 


Last year we made the prettiest little stage you could cut your teeth on and this year we want to further honor people's contributions by creating an even more magical space.


To create this large piece, we'll be working very closely with half a dozen skilled apprentices who are interested in learning more about wood-working and glass.  You will be directly contributing to the growth of their craft and experience as artists. 


What We Need & What You Get

$6,000 covers, material cost, sound and light rental, and transport - in that order of cost.  The materials budget represents the vast majority.  While much of the magic in our former efforts was largely in dressing up simple materials (plywood and 2x4s), with this project we want to invest in maple, cherry and walnut.  We hope to create something that can be cherished and used by our community for years to come. 


The sound and light rental portion is also noteworthy as we will be recording the scheduled acts so that they will have these materials for their own promotional purposes.  So, you're not just building a stage, you're helping to potentially further the careers of dozens of other artists too. 


Finally, this isn't an operation we can simply throw in the back of our van.  It takes truck rentals and significant logistics planning and dollars. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for your support.  If our project and our message resonates with you, please pass along and share on social media sites and with your friends and family. : )

story:
WHO WE ARE

Maximum Exposure is a student run Arts Festival that exhibits the work of students from Ryerson University's School of Image Arts. From the beginning of April until the first weekend of May, hundreds of Image Arts students have the opportunity to show their work to the public in professional venues situated in Toronto's Queen West gallery district. Maximum Exposure is open to the public and includes free admission to all exhibitions of photography, interactive new media works, public street art, and film screenings which allows as many people as possible to see the extraordinary work of students.
 
The Maximum Exposure Coordinating Team consists of 4 graduating Photography student from Ryerson, Kyle Brohman, Nicole Kim, Christopher Jacques Lacroix, and Lindsay Voegelin.

WHAT YOU WILL BE SUPPORTING

To best show the work of over 200 emerging artists, Maximum Exposure has expanded to 7 exhibitions in 4 venues in the Queen West Gallery district and in other Toronto locations. Your support will go towards venue rentals, promotions, installation, and receptions for the exhibition openings. We do not help fund the production of any student work; we simply create a platform for their work to be shown to as many people as possible.

Starting in September, the Maximum Exposure coordinating team began organizing venues, submissions, and multiple fundraising efforts. While we have been successful in securing funding from the University and industry partners, our mandate of keeping the festival free to the public means we still need funds to ensure its success, and the success of future Maximum Exposure Festivals. We are almost there, and with your donation we plan to make this year's festival the best yet!

In return for your generous support, you can receive the following:

- A thank you on our website

- A sticker and button set

- Warm and Fuzzy feelings ! (Guaranteed)

- A copy of Function Magazine, the annual Publication by The School of Image Arts

- A limited edition print of the Maximum Exposure Starburst

- A Maximum Exposure Portfolio curated by the Coordinating Team, limited edition of 17

- An invitation to the Industry Preview Reception and a guided tour of the entire festival.

THE IMPACT

By supporting the efforts of Maximum Exposure you are investing in the future generation of artists and cultural innovators. By investing in culture, you are supporting the vibrancy, creativity, and sense of community of not just the artists involved, but the cultural community of Toronto and the thousands of patrons that attend any part of the festival.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

The best way you can support Maximum Exposure would be to attend the Festival itself! See our website for details on dates and locations.

If you would rather receive a tax receipt for your donation, please contact us at maxex@ryerson.ca for more details.

story:
Redunder Dome 2013!

From the remnants of Metal Camp and Smash Club, De Camp proudly presents REDUNDER DOME!  For those of you who have never been to the Burning Man Project, our inspiration comes from Deathguild's Thunderdome. However, the original idea stems from the movie, Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome. De Camp's Redunder Dome will be very similar with bungee harnesses and foam fighting weapons. Our matches wil be held dring the daytime, Thursday - Saturday. 3ish - 8ish? Find a lover, find a friend, find an enemy, find Ishe, and come battle in Rendunder Dome 2013!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to be sure we our construction of this contraption is unfailingly soild to esure the safety of the participants. The dome requires 1 1/4 inch steel conduit to be safe and that stuf is a pretty penny.  We need to build four separate harnesses and a bunch of the foam bats to keep all you combatants in Redunder heaven.

All monies will go to the fabrication and engineering of Redunder Dome and any contribution to helping us achieve our (De)ath Guild dreams are greatly appreciated.  

Depending on your level of contribution, we are offering some sweet-ass Pirate Shwag Perks such as: necklaces, stickers, flags, "pirate booty", an Antiqued Bronze Apogaea Lapel Pin, and even some very special experiences partying with the pirates at Apo and at our De Camp Russian Party, after we get back from Apo!
