story:
Make Something Good Happen

To commemorate and raise money for the build-out of the NEW Medium Control Retail Store & Studio, we are releasing a limited edition, screen print to encapsulate the moment. Each print is hand printed by yours truly, (along with some other sweet goods). 

The new Medium Control space is for YOU too, whether you live near or far. Maybe you became a fan of our work when we met you at one of the many art shows across the USA, Maybe you live in MN, Maybe you grew-up riding with Tommy, Maybe you bought something from us online or in our Duluth Store, Maybe you just LOVE Watson :) The list could go on-and-on, but either way we appreciate all of you and love creating for good people like you. Now that we will have the room necessary to tackle big ideas, YOU fine folks will get to enjoy the fruits of our labor, no matter where you live! That is why we are reaching out to you, so we can all make something good happen. 

If this Medium Control / Indiegogo Project is not 100% funded, the new print will not be made and we will not receive any funding. That's the way this works - ALL OR NOTHING! Check-out the Goods below and make a purchase TODAY to literally transform the walls! 

P.S. The faster we reach our funding goal ($5K) the sooner you will get your new goods! Let's work together to make sure everyone gets their goods before the HOLIDAYS!

Happy Shopping & Our Sincere Thanks,

Tommy + Kristy + Watson

NOW IT'S TIME TO CHECK OUT THE GOODS BELOW - CHEERS

**AFTER PURCHASING WE WILL BE CONTACTING YOU TO FIND OUT YOUR PRODUCT CHOICE (ie. which print or pint glass)

WHERE WE ARE AT TODAY

Our STUDIO is currently in a functioning capacity so our top priority will be to get your goods out to you as quickly as possible. We will do everything in our power to make sure your new goods are shipped before the HOLIDAYS! As mentioned above, the quicker we reach our funding goal the faster the goods will hit your mailbox! 

The RETAIL STORE is "open" in the sense that the doors are open and regular hours are coming soon. We will be OPEN during the final build-out and anticipate all will be completed by Spring 2013. It has already taken many hours of INTENSE labor. However, finishing the interior design and build-out is sure to take MANY more back-breaking hours. We have a set design plan and are definitely up for the CHALLENGE. With inspiration from the Eames Studio and versatility of the Bauhaus Schools, we are excited to continue this process. Right now, Duluth is booming with a ton of new brewpubs, galleries + good eats. We are stoked to be a part of it!

Please help spread the word about our campaign - Cheers

THANKS FOR MAKING SOMETHING GOOD HAPPEN.

The Medium Control.

PS. if you have any questions, leave a comment (near top of page) or send us an email: info@mediumcontrol.com
story_txt:
Make Something Good Happen
To commemorate and raise money for the build-out of the NEW Medium Control Retail Store & Studio, we are releasing a limited edition, screen print to encapsulate the moment. Each print is hand printed by yours truly, (along with some other sweet goods). 
The new Medium Control space is for YOU too, whether you live near or far. Maybe you became a fan of our work when we met you at one of the many art shows across the USA, Maybe you live in MN, Maybe you grew-up riding with Tommy, Maybe you bought something from us online or in our Duluth Store, Maybe you just LOVE Watson :) The list could go on-and-on, but either way we appreciate all of you and love creating for good people like you. Now that we will have the room necessary to tackle big ideas, YOU fine folks will get to enjoy the fruits of our labor, no matter where you live! That is why we are reaching out to you, so we can all make something good happen. 
If this Medium Control / Indiegogo Project is not 100% funded, the new print will not be made and we will not receive any funding. That's the way this works - ALL OR NOTHING! Check-out the Goods below and make a purchase TODAY to literally transform the walls! 
P.S. The faster we reach our funding goal ($5K) the sooner you will get your new goods! Let's work together to make sure everyone gets their goods before the HOLIDAYS!
Happy Shopping & Our Sincere Thanks,
Tommy + Kristy + Watson
NOW IT'S TIME TO CHECK OUT THE GOODS BELOW - CHEERS
**AFTER PURCHASING WE WILL BE CONTACTING YOU TO FIND OUT YOUR PRODUCT CHOICE (ie. which print or pint glass)

WHERE WE ARE AT TODAY
Our STUDIO is currently in a functioning capacity so our top priority will be to get your goods out to you as quickly as possible. We will do everything in our power to make sure your new goods are shipped before the HOLIDAYS! As mentioned above, the quicker we reach our funding goal the faster the goods will hit your mailbox! 
The RETAIL STORE is "open" in the sense that the doors are open and regular hours are coming soon. We will be OPEN during the final build-out and anticipate all will be completed by Spring 2013. It has already taken many hours of INTENSE labor. However, finishing the interior design and build-out is sure to take MANY more back-breaking hours. We have a set design plan and are definitely up for the CHALLENGE. With inspiration from the Eames Studio and versatility of the Bauhaus Schools, we are excited to continue this process. Right now, Duluth is booming with a ton of new brewpubs, galleries + good eats. We are stoked to be a part of it!
Please help spread the word about our campaign - Cheers
THANKS FOR MAKING SOMETHING GOOD HAPPEN.
The Medium Control.
PS. if you have any questions, leave a comment (near top of page) or send us an email: info@mediumcontrol.com

story:
English follows French information

Court résumé

Aidez-nous à la fabrication de la monnaie et des timbres-poste de la République acadienne. Une œuvre conceptuelle de l'artiste Mario Doucette. 

Histoire

Le roi français Louix XV décide d’envoyer une puissante escadre pour reprendre l’Acadie. En 1746, cette grande expédition est confiée au duc d’Anville qui se voit charger 76 navires et environ 13 000 soldats. L’expédition fut la plus grande force navale jamais regroupée vers l’Amérique du Nord avant la Révolution américaine. L’effort pour reprendre l’Acadie fut aussi supporté par l’expédition de Ramezay partie de Québec.

L’expédition fut un échec total. À son arrivée à Chibouctou (port de Halifax), la flotte d’Anville ne compte plus que 3 navires de guerre et quelques transporteurs, les autres navires ayant mis en déroute ou coulé en raison de tempêtes violentes. Beaucoup d’hommes ont péri principalement à cause de manque de vivres, de la dysenterie et du scorbut. Le reste de l’équipage campe sur la plage où plusieurs succombent encore à la maladie. Plus de la moitié des hommes de la flotte étaient morts ou sérieusement malades lorsque le duc d’Anville meurt à son tour par une crise d’apoplexie.

Cette lourde perte a rétabli la position de l’Angleterre en Amérique. Elle a aussi annoncé la chute progressive des intervention militaires françaises. L’Acadie mourut sans espoir.

Ce projet, la République acadienne, propose une version alternative de cette histoire. Nous sommes dans un monde parallèle où le duc d’Anville débarque à Chibouctou avec sa flotte et son équipage intactes. Ses victoires en Acadie mettent fin à la guerre avec l’Angleterre. L’Acadie péninsulaire est de nouveau cédée à la France.

Lors de la Convention nationale de 1881 à Memramcook, le quart des 5 000 délégués votent pour le choix du maintient du statut français alors que les autres votent massivement pour la souveraineté. La France accorde l’indépendance à son ancienne colonie, le 15 août 1882.

La République acadienne possède son drapeau, sa citoyenneté, sa monnaie, ses timbres-poste et sa représentation à l’étranger.

 

Niveau Touriste

La monnaie

La piastre est la monnaie officielle de la République acadienne.

La pièce de monnaie de 1 piastre est circulaire avec un diamètre de 26mm et une épaisseur de 2mm. La pièce est faite de bronze. 

La version la plus courante de la pièce montre la devise et l'insigne de la République acadienne au revers et son ancien président Louis J. Robichaud à l'avers. La représentation du 25e président Louis J. Robichaud sur les pièces de 1 piastre donne à la devise son nom populaire, le « p'tit Louis ».

 

Niveau Citoyenneté

Les timbres-poste

Ce niveau comprend 5 feuilles de timbres-poste pour un total de 121 timbres individuels. 

Ces timbres-poste sont des produits de haute qualité, perforés et imprimés sur du papier gommé de haute qualité, et non des étiquettes auto-adhésives avec une fausse perforation imprimée. Ces timbres fonctionnent avec de l'eau ou de la salive. Comme dans le bon vieux temps!

 

Feuille numéro 1 : 16 x 17cm

  1. Charles Deschamps de Boishébert, 24 x 21mm (15 timbres-poste)
  2. Drapeau de la République acadienne, 24 x 24mm (10 timbres-poste)

 

Feuille numéro 2 : 16 x 16cm

  1. La Dispersion des Acadiens, 24 x 42mm (9 timbres-poste)
  2. Victoire - la Mariecomo, 42 x 24mm (6 timbres-poste)

 

Feuille numéro 3 : 18,5 x 17cm

  1. Antonine Maillet, 34 x 24mm (10 timbres-poste)
  2. La Sagouine - Viola Léger, 34 x 24mm (10 timbres-poste)

 

Feuille numéro 4 : 16,5 x 19cm

  1. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 42mm (10 timbres-poste)
  2. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 21mm (15 timbres-poste)

 

Feuille numéro 5 : 21,5 x 18cm

  1. Chiquita Mére, 34 x 24mm (18 timbres-poste)
  2. Gabriel Sylliboy, 24 x 21mm (18 timbres-poste)

 

Niveau L'Ordre du Bon-Temps

Vous recevrez 2 « p'tit Louis », les timbres-poste du niveau Citoyenneté et en bonus, la feuille numéro 6.

 

Feuille numéro 6 : 16 x 17cm

  1. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 21mm (15 timbres-poste)
  2. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 21mm (15 timbres-poste)

 

Niveau Déportation

Vous recevrez votre propre serment d'allégeance. Vivez l'anxiété du peuple acadien du 18e siècle! Cette sérigraphie sur papier (17 x 21cm) est une reproduction fidèle au serment d'allégeance, signé par Pierre Belliveau en Nouvelle-Écosse en 1768. Vous pouvez choisir votre signataire :

  • Robert Monckton
  • John Winslow
  • Edward Cornwallis
  • Charles Lawrence
  • William Shirley
  • Jeffery Amherst
  • ou autre snoreau de votre choix

 

Puis-je coller les timbres-poste sur des lettres?

Nos timbres ne remplacent pas les timbres-poste réguliers de Postes Canada. Vous pouvez coller le timbre-poste de la République acadienne à l'endos de votre enveloppe sans-soucis. Si vous préférez utiliser le timbre comme d'habitude, évitez de le placer dans le coin supérieur droit de l'enveloppe, en suivant l'exemple ci-dessous :

 

Soutenez la République acadienne

Si vous ne parvenez pas à contribuer financièrement ou si vous souhaitez en faire plus, vous pouvez aider en faisant passer le mot!

Suivez-nous sur Facebook à République acadienne.

 

******************************************

Short Summary

Help us make the coins and postage stamps for the République acadienne. This is a conceptual work by artist Mario Doucette.

History

French King Louix XV decided to send a powerful squadron to retake Acadie. In 1746, this great expedition was under the command of the Duc d’Anville, who was entrusted with 76 ships and about 13,000 soldiers. The expedition was the largest naval force ever assembled to North America before the American Revolution. The effort to retake Acadie was also supported by Ramezay's expedition from Quebec.

The expedition was a complete failure. When d’Anville arrived in Chibouctou (Halifax Harbour), the fleet included only 3 war ships and a few transports; the rest had been scattered or sunk due to severe storms. Many men perished, mainly of food shortages, typhus, dysentery, and scurvy. The remaining crews camped on the beach where many continued to succumb to illness. More than half of the men in the fleet were dead or seriously ill when the Duc d’Anville himself died from a stroke.

This heavy loss restored England's position in North America. It also announced the gradual decline of French military intervention. Acadie was lost forever.

This project, la République acadienne, offers an alternative version of this story. We are in a parallel universe where the Duc d’Anville lands in Chibouctou with his fleet and crew intact. His victories in Acadie ended the war with England. The Peninsular Acadie was again ceded to France.

At the 1881 National Convention in Memramcook, a quarter of the 5,000 delegates voted to remain an overseas territory of France while the others voted overwhelmingly for sovereignty. France granted independence to its former colony on August 15, 1882.

La République acadienne has its flag, citizenship, currency, postage stamps and representation abroad.

 

Level Touriste

The Money

The piastre is the official currency of the République acadienne.

The 1 piastre coin is circular with a diameter of 26mm, and a thickness of 2mm. The coin is made of bronze. 

The current version of the piastre shows the motto and insignia of the République acadienne on the reverse and its former president Louis J. Robichaud on the obverse. The representation of the 25th President Louis J. Robichaud on the 1 piastre coins gives the motto its popular name, the "p’tit Louis".

 

Level Citoyenneté

Postage stamps

This level includes 5 sheets of postage stamps for a total of 121 individual stamps.

These postage stamps are high-quality products, perforated and printed on high quality gummed paper, not self-adhesive labels with printed fake perforation. These stamps work with water or saliva. Like in the good old days!

 

Sheet number 1 : 16 x 17cm

  1. Charles Deschamps de Boishébert, 24 x 21mm (15 timbres-poste)
  2. Flag of the République acadienne, 24 x 24mm (10 timbres-poste)

 

Sheet number 2 : 16 x 16cm

  1. La Dispersion des Acadiens, 24 x 42mm (9 postage stamps)
  2. Victoire - la Mariecomo, 42 x 24mm (6 postage stamps)

 

Sheet number 3 : 18,5 x 17cm

  1. Antonine Maillet, 34 x 24mm (10 postage stamps)
  2. La Sagouine - Viola Léger, 34 x 24mm (10 postage stamps)

 

Sheet number 4 : 16,5 x 19cm

  1. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 42mm (10 postage stamps)
  2. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 21mm (15 postage stamps)

 

Sheet number 5 : 21,5 x 18cm

  1. Chiquita Mére, 34 x 24mm (18 postage stamps)
  2. Gabriel Sylliboy, 24 x 21mm (18 postage stamps)

 

Level L'Ordre du Bon-Temps

You will receive 2 "p'tit Louis" coins, the 5 postage sheets from the Citoyenneté level and a bonus sheet of stamps, sheet number 6.

 

Sheet number 6 : 16 x 17cm

  1. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 21mm (15 postage stamps)
  2. Louis J. Robichaud, 24 x 21mm (15 postage stamps)

 

Level Déportation

You will receive your very own pledge of allegiance. Experience the anxiety of the Acadian people of the 18th century! This serigraph on paper (17 x 21cm) is a faithful reproduction to the oath of allegiance, signed by Pierre Belliveau in Nova Scotia in 1768. You can choose your signatory from the following list:

  • Robert Monckton
  • John Winslow
  • Edward Cornwallis
  • Charles Lawrence
  • William Shirley
  • Jeffery Amherst
  • or another bugger of your choice

 

Can I stick these postage stamps on letters?

Our stamps do not replace regular Canada Post stamps. You can stick the République acadienne postage stamp on the back of your envelope without worry. If you prefer to use the stamp as usual, avoid placing it in the upper right corner of the envelope, following the example below.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to share financially, or want to do more, you can help by spreading the word! 

Please follow us on Facebook at République acadienne.

 

Source des images

Piastre

  • Louis J. Robichaud : Archives provinciales du Nouveau-Brunswick P342-5179a

 

Timbres-poste

Feuille 1

  • Œuvres de Mario Doucette

Feuille 2

  • Œuvres de Mario Doucette

Feuille 3

  • Antonine Maillet : CEAAC - Collection l’Évangéline – E39253
  • La Sagouine : CEAAC - Collection l’Évangéline – E39013

Feuille 4

  • Louis J. Robichaud (gauche) : CEAAC - Collection l’Évangéline – E40193
  • Louis J. Robichaud (droite) : Archives provinciales du Nouveau-Brunswick P1-130

Feuille 5

  • Chiquita Mére : Bureau de la Présidente
  • Gabriel Sylliboy : Courtesy of the Nova Scotia Museum

Feuille 6

  • Louis J. Robichaud (gauche) : Archives provinciales du Nouveau-Brunswick P342-5179a
  • Louis J. Robichaud (droite) : Archives provinciales du Nouveau-Brunswick P342-5179a

story:
MOONMAN25 is the name of the artwork. All the works come from MOONMAN Hand-made Arts Studio founded by Mr. Huayu li. In the 2017 Italian A’Design Award, our works named Robot and Flower Soul were granted with Platinum Award and Gold Award respectively!

More info could be found：

  • https://competition.adesignaward.com/design.php?ID=54635
  • https://competition.adesignaward.com/design.php?ID=54627​

 

What is the MOONMAN25?

Moonman25 is a brand-new artistic form. We have spent two years in research. As its potential and range exceed our imagination, many thoughts and creations await further development. The Moonman Studio has a strong design team, which will complete more amazing artwork with your support.

Moonman25 is artwork and also fashionable decoration. They are totally hand-made, each one infused with the inspirations of the designers, instead of simple duplication. Thus each work is unique, it has a unique artistic form, creating an amazing visual effect in an enclosed and transparent space. With its complicated production craftsmanship and enclosed form, it is beyond duplication and imitation. All of these endow it with the value of collection.

Moonman25 is expensive because of high cost in production and transportation. But you should know it is unique in this world. No similar product is available in the market. It is worthwhile. You are supporting the birth of a great art.

 

We hope that you get more happiness and wonders when Moonman25 joins your life.

 

Why Fund us on Indiegogo?

We are trying to strengthen and expand our team. by creating a crowdfunding project, we hope to raise funds for the production of Moonman25, and share the amazing artwork with the world.
Your support is significant for us. This is a brand-new art realm! Please help us to achieve more creations.​

 

Moonman25 is mainly made from resin and other materials. It has an exquisite and complicated inner structure. With the joining and delicate color depiction, it completes its dreamlike theme. At last the resin is injected and solidified, thus permanently sealing a beautiful moment.

The production involves many craftsmanship procedures: design, sculpture, joining, painting, solidifying, sanding and polishing.

Moonman25 consists of two parts, namely, the main body and the base. The main body is the artwork while the base is a device for emitting the lights. Vibration components are used to control the colors of the lights. Multiple colors are available. By lightly knocking the base, you will certainly find your favorite color effect.

 

So far Moonman25 has four varieties for your selection.

Moonman25-1(Robot): Inside is arranged with a light guiding system to more vividly showcase the flow of energy. This is a perfect artistic demonstration of artificial intelligence.

Moonman25-2(Flower of Life): With the combination of fantasy and exquisiteness, it is an art calming down the soul.

Moonman25-3(Flower Fairy): A dreamlike fairy tale.

Moonman25-4(Flower Soul): A magical flower to show magical colors.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Moonman25-1    78W x 78L x 210H (mm)   Color: Blue
Moonman25-2   78W x 78L x 210H (mm)   Color: Blue
   Moonman25-3   78W x 78L x 150H (mm)   Color: Purple
  Moonman25-4   78W x 78L x 87H (mm)     Color: Purple​

  • The colors above are the original colors of Moonman25. Other colors are also available for tailor-made orders, but you need pay an additional fee of 80 USD for such an tailor-made order.
  • Please understand that due to the hand-made production, each work probably has an tolerance of 10 mm in height.

 

Controls the light source

In the light source part in the base is the vibration device. A light knock on the base controls the light source. Here are the rules:

  • First Knock: White light.
  • Second Knock: Gradient color.
  • Third Knock: Choose the current color. 
  • Fourth Knock: White light. 
  • Fifth Knock: Turn off. 

Ways of Power Supply for the Base

The base of the Moonman25 is powered by USB power source or batteries.

Technical specification

Input:  DC 5V, 240MA (max)
Light bulb: 0.5w RGB 5050 LED four light bulbs
Power cord: USB-DC3.5×1.3

 

About Delivery

In fact, once the activity ends we will immediately begin working. As the works are truly hand-made, each work upon completion will be immediately delivered. The delivery follows the orders of the purchase, which means that whoever buys it first will get a Moonman25 first.

Please note: backers are responsible for paying any import fees/duties/taxes

 

 

Contact

If you would like to know anything regarding the future designs and the Moonman Studio, please refer to our relevant media.

  • www.moonman25.com
  • www.facebook.com/huayu.li.96
  • https://twitter.com/HuayuLi25
  • E-mail: huayuli25@gmail.com

https://competition.adesignaward.com/design.php?ID=54635

story:
Hello! My name is Chelsea Raflo and I'm a visual artist. I very recently (last week) graduated from the MFA program in studio art at Florida State University. Before that, I was active within the arts community in Atlanta (my home city) for about five years, and before that, I graduated from the studio art program at Kenyon College in Ohio. 

Here is my website if you would like to see some of my work: www.chelsearaflo.com.

I was just selected to be an artist-in-residence at Artspace in Raleigh, North Carolina as part of their Regional Emerging Artist Residency Program.  :O :) wow! Thanks Artspace :D :D

For more info on this vibrant and well-respected art center, check out this video made for their 30-year anniversary.

The residency is a six-month program (July - January), which is kinda rare- the majority of residency programs in the United States are anywhere from one to three month periods.

I will be going to Artspace to focus on soft sculpture, textiles, and traditional methods of garment construction. Raleigh has a rich history when it comes to the textile industry, so there are a lot of resources available for me to explore. 

The Artspace residency is a little different from some other programs in that it is much more public: my studio space will be in their downtown location, which gets a considerable amount of foot traffic, is open for First Friday art walks, etc. I'll be teaching workshops and organizing self-initiated events at the center. They encourage community partnerships and collaboration, and I'll be working alongside a lot of talented and creative people. After three years of what we like to call "artistic incubation" here at FSU, I'm totally ready to change gears, open up, and put myself out there in a more deliberate way.

I have plans for a new body of work, but also for some wearable collections inspired by all the stuff that I love about sculpture, drawing, and painting. In the "perks" section, you'll see that donations of $100 or more will get you your own custom piece of wearable art. More details on this will soon emerge! Emerge.

THE THING IS...this opportunity is UNPAID- that is, in cash dollars. So while it won't cost me anything to participate, there are the associated relocation costs, new housing, supplies, paying my bills, eating, and paying my ghoulish undergrad student loans that are juuuuust cackling their little cackles now that I'm out of school forever.

ALSO, during this time, I was offered a scholarship to a weeklong workshop making cement jewelry at Anderson Ranch Arts Center in Colorado- another great opportunity and one that ties in directly to my goals for the residency! This one, too, comes with some expenses- namely, flying out to Colorado, housing costs for one week in Aspen, and supplies (overall totaling about $1500).

Like I said, I just graduated...so I don't have a full-time job yet- in Raleigh or anywhere. I'm committing to six months as an artist-in-residence without knowing where I'll land once I get there, which is why I'm crowdfunding for a safety net. 

I'm fortunate enough to be adjuncting an online class through FSU, and I'm no stranger to juggling my art practice with bartending and some side jobs. But I need your support to get out there and get by! Think of it as a kindhearted graduation present, or a generous tax write-off, or- OR- maybe you genuinely appreciate my artwork and you would like to see it flourish. All of these things can be true. 

Thank you for reading this and please know that any amount helps, for real! 

 

If you're curious why my fundraising goal has been set at $4000:

Relocation (one month of paying rent on two places so I don't break my lease + new security deposit + U-Haul truck ): ~$1300

Supplies (fixing or replacing my broken computer + monthly budget of at least $100 for materials + sewing machine of my own bc the one I have now is a loan): ~$1500

Life costs* (phone bill, rent/utilities, car insurance, food, student loans, miscellaneous): $1200/month min.*

Anderson Ranch costs: ~$1500 (see above)

*HEY BTW, I don't want to imply that I think my wants/needs are anyone else's responsibility. However, the fact is that I will be doing a high level of job-like work for six months without any guaranteed level of job-like compensation, and your support literally increases the amount of hours in the day that I am able to spend in my studio, versus outside employment. My point here is not that I don't feel that I should be working anywhere in addition to my studio practice- it's simply that help...is helpful...and makes the balancing of multiple income streams much more doable! I hope you get it!

THANK YOU FOR READING! 

 

(P.S.: Indiegogo informed me that campaigns with videos receive 2000% more funding toward their goal than campaigns without. Lol. Ok then... Here u go. ^^^

Thank you to Neil Bromhall at www.rightplants4me.co.uk, who made the original video that I APPROPRIATED. Also to the "24/7 Lofi hip hop radio" channel from College Music on Youtube for the song that I looped, please don't sue me as I am clearly NOT good for it.)

story:
Short Summary

Gigsville is celebrating it's 20th anniversary on the playa.  So we thought we would try something new to mark the occasion and bring some lights.  Luckily, while attending Burning Flipside in Texas, some friends had already produced such a project.  The 240 foot L2C Screen was created by a group of Austin Burners led by Chainsaw and !Bob.

What We Need & What You Get

We are working to get the wall from Austin TX to Black Rock City.  This campaign is to pay for making it playa ready and for transportation on the community truck.

If you contribute at least $10 you get a special commemorative patch.

The Impact

Gigsville has always been known as the Black Hole of Black Rock, even when we try to make it otherwise.  We once built an Uberman partially to help us find our way home.

This year we have been placed at the 3:00 keyhole on the Esplanade.  We need to step it up and make sure that we can find our way home with 120 feet of bad ass blinkie.  In addition to color goodness, it can do text and boy do we have some ideas for that.

Credits

Special thanks to photos by Dave "Rabbitt" LeClair (Blinkie wall with Castle in front), Bean Noneya (wall with Chainsaw and Bob in front of it), Justin Long (video with castle in front of wall), and Bill Blome (video of just the wall), 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any cash currently, but still want to contribute:

  • If you'll be on the playa we will need help with setup, maintenance and tear down.  Let us know if you want to be on the crew!
  • Please share this campaign with friends online!

story:
NARS Foundation 2019 Year End Fundraiser

The NARS Foundation is excited to announce our 2019 Year End Fundraiser! Launching alongside #GivingTuesday on December 3rd, we ask for your support to help propel the NARS Foundation into a successful new year of programming in 2020.  Every dollar you donate will go directly towards next year's Exhibition, International Residency, and Educational Outreach Programs.

 

Who are we? 

The New York Art Residency and Studios (NARS) Foundation is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit arts organization committed to supporting artists and curators on an international level as well engaging the local community in Brooklyn and the Greater New York area. NARS provides an array of creative support services and professional development opportunities for emerging and mid-career artists through short-term integrated residency programs, affordable long-term studio spaces, progressive exhibition programs, international exchanges, and engaging public programs that foster global understanding and dynamic cross-cultural dialogues. These services operate in conjunction with our community outreach initiatives to promote greater accessibility to contemporary art for the under-served local community in south Brooklyn. Our mission is to present diverse platforms on which to nurture creative inspiration and innovative cross-pollination of ideas.

How Will $5,000 Help Us?

In order to reach our goal of $5,000 by December 31st and we need your help! By donating to our Year End Fundraiser, you will ensure the development and growth of our programming in 2020.  With our goal reached by December 31st, we will be able to ...

 

  • Create a successful 2020 exhibition program in our Main Gallery and Project Space, including exhibitions by The Immigrant Artist Biennial as well as group and solo presentations. 
  • Provide visual arts education to our local Sunset Park community by inviting teaching artists for our Free Family Saturday Workshop series and After School Animation Class as a part of our Educational Outreach Program.
  •  Fund one Residency Artist Fellowship for our International Artist Residency Program.

How Can YOU Help?

 

Join us on December 3rd for #GivingTuesday for the launch of our Indiegogo Campaign!

Take a moment to read through "our story" and all of our exciting incentives, like the Raffle Tickets for our Holiday FUNdraiser Party on December 17th, or Portfolio Reviews, or a studio visit from NARS Staff!

Pledge your support by donating to our campaign from December 3rd – December 31st.

Check back throughout our campaign and see our updates, progress and continue to pledge your support.  

Share our campaign with your friends and family! (Details on how to share below)

Can't make a donation today?

That's ok! There are so many other ways you can support the NARS Foundation.

  1. Share! Every share helps!  Whether you're able to donate to our cause or donate your time by promoting our campaign, YOU will help us make a difference. Share this campaign with your colleagues, your friends, your bosses, artists, curators, administrators, and fellow art lovers. 
     
  2. Join us for our Holiday FUNdraiser party at NARS on December 17th. 
     
  3. You can also support us by using Amazon Smile every time you shop on Amazon, at no additional cost to you! Download the free Smilematic browser plug-in here to ensure you're shopping at smile.amazon.com every time you use Amazon. Amazon will donate a percentage of each of your purchases directly to NARS, free to you! A little goes a long way. Support while you shop!

                                                                                              

Testimonials

 

"One of the biggest value of the residency for me were the studio visits, they helped me to see my work in context, it provided the platform for creating valuable connections and through the feedback shaped my future development of my art practice.  On my return to Ireland my practice viewed in a new light and my work got curated and selected to galleries and to residencies ,including a recent review in the Irish Times, which I could not have dreamt of it before. "

- Brigitta Varadi, NARS Residency Alumni (2014 Season I)

 

"My family and I have attended the Free Family Workshops for over a year now. My boys are 8 years old and 5 years old. They love coming to NARS!  We've met great artists like Jose Arenas and Ellen Coleman Izzo. Our first experience was in May 2014 with Jose Arenas. NARS was hosting an Open Studios event. We walked into all the galleries and visited with the artists. My boys were then invited to create their own art. My sons were so proud of their work that they invited the artists to come see what they've created. To their disappointment, the artists had to stay in their spaces during the event. So my oldest took his art "on the road." He walked into all studios to show his own masterpiece.  NARS provided my boys the time and space to explore their artistic side.  In the past, we usually sat back when the boys attended art workshops. At NARS we can't help but be part of the experience. Even Dad learned to knit with plastic bags. Each visit we made to the NARS, the boys experienced art through different avenues. Each time, the boys came home proud. Our house has become their art gallery. Thank you, NARS"

- Lisa Fung-Fernandes, Local Brooklyn Resident

 

"I was an artist in residence at NARS foundation during 2014. The residency was an amazing experience from every perspective; I had six months and a spacious studio to develop a new body of work, but more important, I had the opportunity to meet and get the feedback from other residents (coming from allover) and from several art professionals that included independent curators, artists and gallery owners.  The exercise of having regular meetings helped me gain confidence in my work and in the way I should present it to others. The residency gave me a lot of exposure and many positive things have happened in my career after this experience. NARS staff is very helpful and supportive; they have continued to support my practice until today. Thank you NARS Foundation!"

- Denise Treizman, NARS Residency Alum (2014 Season IV,  2015 Season I)

 

"During my residency at NARS Foundation in 2015, I had a very exciting experience not only in producing new works in my studio, but also gaining feedback on my practice from visitors of different backgrounds.  This professional feedback was very crucial to me as an artist who recently moved to the New York art world, hoping to be part of it.  This kind of lasting dialogue between an artist and professional I believe is very helpful. It creates a context of critical thinking and also a potential to develop the depth of a further discourse in personal methodology and philosophy. All artists in residence came from all over the world. We often hung out and shared thoughts with each other in our studios. It has a very energetic vibe. The NARS residency has been very supportive to my career in many ways."

- Tuo Wang, NARS Residency Alum (2015 Season I)

 

"Having a residency with NARS was a great opportunity for me. Not only did I have studio space to work, but a range of studio visitors who I could show my work to. This was invaluable not just as a networking tool, but also gave me more experience in speaking about my work to different people from a range of artistic backgrounds and perspectives. This in turn inspired me in my approach to my own work. Thanks to one of the visits, I was invited to screen some of my videos as part of a show at Vox Populi, Philadelphia, curated by Katya Grokhovsky. I also travelled to Miami to do a live performance at The Harold Golen Gallery.  Another great aspect to the residency is the weekly events planned at NARS. This meant that I got to know the other studio artists, which was a good networking tool, but even more so, a social one. We organised social events within New York, art-related and otherwise."

- Cassandra Tytler, NARS Residency Alum (2015 Season I)

 

"The NARS residency represented a wonderful and exciting time for me. For the first time post-grad school, I had a studio of my own, with sufficient space and resource to fully realize new work. My community of fellow artists around me were unique and irreplaceable. It was really great to be able to make work in the midst of such a strong and supportive network of people. My residency gave me the opportunity to best showcase my work of that time during beneficial studio visits and critiques. Thanks to my NARS residency, I was able to complete more ambitious work that would be featured in group shows, including David Krut Projects and ArtGate Gallery in Chelsea."  

- Brian Lund, NARS Residency Alum (2011 Season II)

 

 

 

How do I share NARS' campaign? 

Send a link to our campaign to your friends and family asking to help donate to our arts non-profit during their year-end support.  (Mention our super exciting perks!)

Click "Share on Facebook" at the top of our campaign to promote our event on your Facebook page or profile!  It's super easy and super accessible!  

You can also share our campaign on your twitter page or email by clicking on the buttons below "Our Story"

Copy and Paste a message of support to your social media pages: "Donate today to the NARS Foundation's Year End Fundraiser!  Help support programming for the arts in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Click HERE to donate today." 

                                                                                                                

 

We can't do this without YOUR help!

 

As an arts not-for-profit organization, we depend  on the support of our trusted friends, followers and admirers.  Since 2010, we've been dedicated to fostering exhibition, residency and educational programming to our local and international community.  With your help, we want to continue to provide resources for artists, teachers, students and families.    

 

Help us reach our $5,000 goal by making a tax-deductible donation or receiving one of our exciting perks.  Our incentives were graciously donated by NARS Alumni, teachers, artists, staff and friends.  Their support helped to make this fundraiser possible! 

 

Take a moment during your year-end donating to support NARS and help us continue to run and operate our programming in 2020.
story_txt:
NARS Foundation 2019 Year End FundraiserThe NARS Foundation is excited to announce our 2019 Year End Fundraiser! Launching alongside #GivingTuesday on December 3rd, we ask for your support to help propel the NARS Foundation into a successful new year of programming in 2020.  Every dollar you donate will go directly towards next year's Exhibition, International Residency, and Educational Outreach Programs. Who are we? The New York Art Residency and Studios (NARS) Foundation is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit arts organization committed to supporting artists and curators on an international level as well engaging the local community in Brooklyn and the Greater New York area. NARS provides an array of creative support services and professional development opportunities for emerging and mid-career artists through short-term integrated residency programs, affordable long-term studio spaces, progressive exhibition programs, international exchanges, and engaging public programs that foster global understanding and dynamic cross-cultural dialogues. These services operate in conjunction with our community outreach initiatives to promote greater accessibility to contemporary art for the under-served local community in south Brooklyn. Our mission is to present diverse platforms on which to nurture creative inspiration and innovative cross-pollination of ideas.How Will $5,000 Help Us?In order to reach our goal of $5,000 by December 31st and we need your help! By donating to our Year End Fundraiser, you will ensure the development and growth of our programming in 2020.  With our goal reached by December 31st, we will be able to ... 
Create a successful 2020 exhibition program in our Main Gallery and Project Space, including exhibitions by The Immigrant Artist Biennial as well as group and solo presentations. 
Provide visual arts education to our local Sunset Park community by inviting teaching artists for our Free Family Saturday Workshop series and After School Animation Class as a part of our Educational Outreach Program.
 Fund one Residency Artist Fellowship for our International Artist Residency Program.
How Can YOU Help? Join us on December 3rd for #GivingTuesday for the launch of our Indiegogo Campaign!Take a moment to read through "our story" and all of our exciting incentives, like the Raffle Tickets for our Holiday FUNdraiser Party on December 17th, or Portfolio Reviews, or a studio visit from NARS Staff!Pledge your support by donating to our campaign from December 3rd – December 31st.Check back throughout our campaign and see our updates, progress and continue to pledge your support.  Share our campaign with your friends and family! (Details on how to share below)Can't make a donation today?That's ok! There are so many other ways you can support the NARS Foundation.
Share! Every share helps!  Whether you're able to donate to our cause or donate your time by promoting our campaign, YOU will help us make a difference. Share this campaign with your colleagues, your friends, your bosses, artists, curators, administrators, and fellow art lovers.  
Join us for our Holiday FUNdraiser party at NARS on December 17th.  
You can also support us by using Amazon Smile every time you shop on Amazon, at no additional cost to you! Download the free Smilematic browser plug-in here to ensure you're shopping at smile.amazon.com every time you use Amazon. Amazon will donate a percentage of each of your purchases directly to NARS, free to you! A little goes a long way. Support while you shop!
                                                                                               Testimonials "One of the biggest value of the residency for me were the studio visits, they helped me to see my work in context, it provided the platform for creating valuable connections and through the feedback shaped my future development of my art practice.  On my return to Ireland my practice viewed in a new light and my work got curated and selected to galleries and to residencies ,including a recent review in the Irish Times, which I could not have dreamt of it before. "- Brigitta Varadi, NARS Residency Alumni (2014 Season I) "My family and I have attended the Free Family Workshops for over a year now. My boys are 8 years old and 5 years old. They love coming to NARS!  We've met great artists like Jose Arenas and Ellen Coleman Izzo. Our first experience was in May 2014 with Jose Arenas. NARS was hosting an Open Studios event. We walked into all the galleries and visited with the artists. My boys were then invited to create their own art. My sons were so proud of their work that they invited the artists to come see what they've created. To their disappointment, the artists had to stay in their spaces during the event. So my oldest took his art "on the road." He walked into all studios to show his own masterpiece.  NARS provided my boys the time and space to explore their artistic side.  In the past, we usually sat back when the boys attended art workshops. At NARS we can't help but be part of the experience. Even Dad learned to knit with plastic bags. Each visit we made to the NARS, the boys experienced art through different avenues. Each time, the boys came home proud. Our house has become their art gallery. Thank you, NARS"- Lisa Fung-Fernandes, Local Brooklyn Resident "I was an artist in residence at NARS foundation during 2014. The residency was an amazing experience from every perspective; I had six months and a spacious studio to develop a new body of work, but more important, I had the opportunity to meet and get the feedback from other residents (coming from allover) and from several art professionals that included independent curators, artists and gallery owners.  The exercise of having regular meetings helped me gain confidence in my work and in the way I should present it to others. The residency gave me a lot of exposure and many positive things have happened in my career after this experience. NARS staff is very helpful and supportive; they have continued to support my practice until today. Thank you NARS Foundation!"- Denise Treizman, NARS Residency Alum (2014 Season IV,  2015 Season I) "During my residency at NARS Foundation in 2015, I had a very exciting experience not only in producing new works in my studio, but also gaining feedback on my practice from visitors of different backgrounds.  This professional feedback was very crucial to me as an artist who recently moved to the New York art world, hoping to be part of it.  This kind of lasting dialogue between an artist and professional I believe is very helpful. It creates a context of critical thinking and also a potential to develop the depth of a further discourse in personal methodology and philosophy. All artists in residence came from all over the world. We often hung out and shared thoughts with each other in our studios. It has a very energetic vibe. The NARS residency has been very supportive to my career in many ways."- Tuo Wang, NARS Residency Alum (2015 Season I) "Having a residency with NARS was a great opportunity for me. Not only did I have studio space to work, but a range of studio visitors who I could show my work to. This was invaluable not just as a networking tool, but also gave me more experience in speaking about my work to different people from a range of artistic backgrounds and perspectives. This in turn inspired me in my approach to my own work. Thanks to one of the visits, I was invited to screen some of my videos as part of a show at Vox Populi, Philadelphia, curated by Katya Grokhovsky. I also travelled to Miami to do a live performance at The Harold Golen Gallery.  Another great aspect to the residency is the weekly events planned at NARS. This meant that I got to know the other studio artists, which was a good networking tool, but even more so, a social one. We organised social events within New York, art-related and otherwise."- Cassandra Tytler, NARS Residency Alum (2015 Season I) "The NARS residency represented a wonderful and exciting time for me. For the first time post-grad school, I had a studio of my own, with sufficient space and resource to fully realize new work. My community of fellow artists around me were unique and irreplaceable. It was really great to be able to make work in the midst of such a strong and supportive network of people. My residency gave me the opportunity to best showcase my work of that time during beneficial studio visits and critiques. Thanks to my NARS residency, I was able to complete more ambitious work that would be featured in group shows, including David Krut Projects and ArtGate Gallery in Chelsea."  - Brian Lund, NARS Residency Alum (2011 Season II)   How do I share NARS' campaign? Send a link to our campaign to your friends and family asking to help donate to our arts non-profit during their year-end support.  (Mention our super exciting perks!)Click "Share on Facebook" at the top of our campaign to promote our event on your Facebook page or profile!  It's super easy and super accessible!  You can also share our campaign on your twitter page or email by clicking on the buttons below "Our Story"Copy and Paste a message of support to your social media pages: "Donate today to the NARS Foundation's Year End Fundraiser!  Help support programming for the arts in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Click HERE to donate today."                                                                                                                  We can't do this without YOUR help! As an arts not-for-profit organization, we depend  on the support of our trusted friends, followers and admirers.  Since 2010, we've been dedicated to fostering exhibition, residency and educational programming to our local and international community.  With your help, we want to continue to provide resources for artists, teachers, students and families.     Help us reach our $5,000 goal by making a tax-deductible donation or receiving one of our exciting perks.  Our incentives were graciously donated by NARS Alumni, teachers, artists, staff and friends.  Their support helped to make this fundraiser possible!  Take a moment during your year-end donating to support NARS and help us continue to run and operate our programming in 2020.

story:
Check out Geodesic! at Lightning in a Bottle!

Geodesic! at Lightning in a Bottle 2013 from James Hurwitz on Vimeo.

 

The Vision

My goal is to create transformational experiences. Through immersive interactive environments, I aim to empower the participant by shifting their consciousness, presenting an opportunity for personal reflection, revelation, and transformation.

Geodesic! invites you to interact, reflect, and transform while being bathed by light, sound and even smell. It's sheer skin comes to life with fractal geometry while LEDs glow with a spectrum of color. Ultrasonic sensors on the inside of the dome will allow you to interact with and shape the experience.

Art is multidimensional, it is about every experience and interaction that happens because of it, and the connections and communities that are made around it. By challenging our boundaries, combining ideas, and encouraging interactions, a new world is created around us.

With your help, Geodesic! will be co-creating at Burning Man in August.

Together, we Co-Create our Reality.

What is it?


 

Geodesic! is a 16ft 3V self-built metal conduit geodesic dome covered with a translucent sheer fabric so it can be experienced form both inside and out.

4ft Giza proportion pyramids house 3 2200 lumen projectors that envelop Geodesic! with fractal geometry and immersive animations. 

Addressable RGB LEDs at each vertex of the dome are controlled by an Arduino which interfaces with a MacBook Pro. LEDs, Projections, and mist, can be controlled via midi by Ableton Live, Resolume Avenue, and Ultrasonic Sensors.

Two speakers provide ambient soundscapes and effects which further propel the participant into metaphysical bliss.

Read more about Geodesic! at BlueRoar.com

 

Lucidity: The Totems' Return

At its festival debut, Geodesic! provided a participatory container to interact, reflect, and transform into a state of lucidity.

Geodesic! at Lucidity The Totems' Return 2013 from James Hurwitz on Vimeo.

 

Situated in the I AM HEALING Sanctuary, Geodesic! created a sacred space which transformed itself as well as it's occupants.

By the end of the night, as people returned from the dance floor, the dome was packed. Lucinda Loves lead a group sound healing incorporating her crystal bowls and tuning forks with the projections and soundscapes. We activated and rejuvenated with light, sound, cacao, incense, essential oils, and much needed massage after a days worth of ecstatic dancing, transforming Geodesic! into a multisensory healing experience!

Geodesic! needs you!

So far Geodesic! has been entirely self-funded. This includes the 16ft 3V dome, 3 projectors, sheer cover, LEDs, speaker system, foam tiles, electronics, and materials.

Geodesic! needs your help to get through the final stages.

The Giza pyramid enclosures are still being built and need to be fitted with access panels and adequate ventilation.

Transporting and providing electricity for Geodesic! is the largest forth coming expense.

Purchasing a generator is much more economical than renting one for multiple weeks sporadically throughout the years. With it's own generator, Geodesic! and it's future projects will be entirely energy sufficient. 

By donating towards a generator, it will be much more affordable for Geodesic! to come to a music and arts festival near you!

Your donations will help to create an experience that will be cherished by many.

 

The Goal

In order to travel to Burning man, Geodesic! needs at least $2400

$800 to purchase a used Honda EU2000i generator

$125 for generator gasoline

$500 for trailer rental 

$500 for workshop rental (Pyramids)

$250 for remaining materials (Plywood, 2x2s, misc. construction)

 

The Extra Mile

Geodesic! could use some maintenance. The hand made sheer cover has become worn and stained. 

$600 would allow me to have a new more durable and form fitting cover professionally made to last for many more seasons and installations!

$100 would allow me to order new LEDs.

The current LEDs were custom ordered but were spray painted black after the fact, consequently the black paint has been rubbing off in the heat and staining the white cover. 

$500 Geodesic! will be able to go to Symbiosis!

If the goal is not met, funds will be used to fulfill perks and rent equipment rather than purchase it. When the goal is exceeded, Geodesic! will be able to travel to even more festivals and gatherings!

One of a kind Perks!

I am very excited to offer you lovingly handmade, one of a kind items in exchange for your donations!

$5 Love and gratitude

Undying love and gratitude for being a part of Geodesic!

$10 Geodesic! Sticker

A beautiful color-shifting iridescent sticker that will remind you that you are shining light that made Geodesic! possible. Your water bottle will thank you too.

If the goal is met you will also receive a Geodesic! decal.

 

$15 Heart Diffraction Glasses

A pair of Custom Heart Diffraction Glasses to call your own! There will be ones to share inside Geodesic!, transforming light into hearts to remind you that you are LOVE.

$20 Iridescent Bracelet

A hand made one of a kind Iridescent Bracelet, to shine your light wherever you go.

 

$25 Geodesic! essential oil room and body spray 4oz.

A large, hand blended, 4oz. bottle of the essential oil spray used in the mist inside Geodesic!, so that you may enliven senses wherever you go. (Lavendar, Lemon, Eucalyptus, Palo Santo)

$40 Geodesic! 3D printed pendant

A 3D printed metal Geodesic! pendant, so that you may remember your intricate and beautiful nature.

(design subject to change)

$45 Geodesic! Galore

Iridescent Bracelet, Geodesic! spray, and a sticker!

$75 Double the Love

Two pendants, for you and a friend!

$100 Miniature Geodesic!

A 3D printed model of Geodesic! Keep it on your desk, in your car, or on your head.

$125 Sound reactive ORB

Transform spaces with a self-contained 3 mode, sound reactive ORB lamp.

This ORB is made of glass and will react to music with a powerful LED array controlled by an Arduino and a microphone.

Mode 1 Continuous Rainbow Fade

Mode 2 Color of Sound Reactive

Mode 3 Rainbow Fade Reactive 

(shipping not included, video is of the prototype)

$185 Sound reactive Geodesic! 

Have a miniature sound reactive Geodesic! Same as the ORB, but with a 3D printed Geodesic! instead of glass.

$280 Geodesic! Ultimate

A little of everything. Undying Gratitude, Stickers, Heart Diffraction Glasses, Iridescent Bracelet, Geodesic! Spray, Geodesic! Pendant, Sound Reactive Geodesic!

$600 Geodesic! will come to your event

Maybe it's your birthday, or your music and arts festival, or both! Geodesic! will be there!

(Transportation out of California not included.)

$800 Name the Generator! 

Your donation goes directly towards purchase of a generator, and you get to pick the name! Name it after yourself, or whatever you'd like! You will also receive a Sound reactive Geodesic!

$2000 your own 3v Geodesic dome

I will build you the frame of a dome the same size as Geodesic!

(shipping not included)

Other Ways You Can Help

This is a flexible funding campaign, so Geodesic! will be able to use whatever you donate.

Spread the word to your friends!

If you love Geodesic! please share it with the people that you love!

Remember... 

Together, we Co-Create our reality. 

Love,

James

story:
The project

Traditional paintings were often funded by patrons on the condition they were included within the work; this project takes that idea a step further.

Each patron will have his or her name forever carved by hand into the woodcut and printed also by hand to be part of a much larger work.

The size of the patrons area is determined by how much funding they give, 1/2 inch square per £1 donation, this will show how much they truly value the art and allow them to show everyone.

This first instalment will be 8'x4', room for 18,432 prints, the first of 54 similar works.

The final aim of the project is to reach One Million prints, about 1736 square feet of ink, one of the largest wood cuts in the world and years of work for me.

Where the money goes

I live, work and study in the centre of London, a student of fine art, a Scout leader and a retail assistant for Cotswolds outdoors, money and time seem to constantly be in short supply.

The majority of the money will go towards funding my overseas studies. I will be spending 5 months abroad next year learning all there is to learn from the world and bringing it back here to expand my art and hopefully make an impact on the art world.

I spend three days of the week working in retail just to survive in central London. The extra funding will mean I can concentrate more on my studies and give me a chance to start volunteering again with the Scout Association during my weekends.

Other Ways You Can Help

This is a huge project for me so every little helps.

Even if you decide not to contribute please spread the word with the Indiegogo share tools, the more momentum I can get the greater my concept gets.

Also check out the rest of the site, there are some great projects around that need as much help as i do.

story:
Hello Indiegogo! It all started right here, so we could think of no better way to celebrate our 25th design than with all of you! 

It is amazing how much has happened this past year and it is all thanks to you! As promised in our original Kickstarter project, we started our own website, www.billetspin.com and the BilletSPIN Facebook group. We produced 24 new designs, each one sellling out in record time. One of our customers even created a fan website with photos of all our designs!

BilletSPIN is now one of the leading names in precision tops. The Kraken became one of the most sought-after tops ever made when it was featured in a famous knife reviewer's YouTube video. Our customer base presently spans the entire world.

Accidents happen... 

It hasn't been all good, though. Our 5-axis Mazak Integrex machine recently experienced a devastating crash. It was a very costly repair and a major blow to our business. BilletSPIN rallied to meet the challenge.

Our Mission

Our passion and principles drive us to create unique, sophisticated designs that look great and perform on the highest level. They have helped us navigate past the difficulties of starting a new business. They have led us to new friends in all corners of the world. 

That brings us to right here, right now. Our 25th design embodies the same passion and principles that guide us, our company and our fans.

Presenting the BilletSPIN Navigator

Presenting the BilletSPIN Navigator. The Navigator is a three piece top consisting of an outer collar, inner disc and stem. The contact point is a ceramic bearing ball which is not only durable but precise. By using three pieces, we are able to create stunning material contrasts. The compass themed inner disc and outer collar lends the Navigator its name.

We wanted the Navigator to be visually stunning and have the performance to match, so we chose our 4 best selling material combinations to bring to Indiegogo. The Navigator is 1.1" in diameter and available in combinations of copper, bronze and stainless steel. For those looking for the longest spinning combination, the SS/Cu/SS averages about 30 seconds extra spin time. Copper is the heaviest of the three materials but also the softest. Stainless Steel is the most durable. Bronze has the most luster, is lighter than copper and is not quite as durable as Stainless Steel.


Additional Standard Material choices!

Due to the overwhelming support we are adding two more standard material options. For those of you that chose a perk for more than one top these are eligible to be chosen. They also have their own perk for those that just found the project!


NEW Exotic Materials

Due to the overwhelming support, we are also adding three exotics materials to the project! YOU CANNOT CHOOSE THESE AS PART OF YOUR MULTIPLE TOP PERK!!! The only way to get them is to pledge on the exotic perks. Shipping is included and you can pledge on multiple perks. This means even if you pledged prior to now you can still pledge for these as well! Due to the extreme costs of these materials the prices are higher and they are all limited quantities!


Whatever combination you choose, the Navigator is easily capable of spin times over ten minutes, as demonstrated in the video below. 


Jim Skelton Testimonial: I just wanted to give a quick testimonial. I own the prototype Navigator (Rich was kind enough to share my photos of it on his campaign), and out of all the BilletSpin Tops that I own, the Navigator is my favorite spinner, hands-down. It has a more compact size in both diameter and stem height than most of the others I own, and that translates to a different feeling when you spin it. It’s much easier to get a stable spin right away, and even when you don’t, it stabilizes faster than any other BilletSpin I own. My average times have been between 9 minutes and 10 minutes on my steel-over-copper version. It’s also a gorgeous design, with the cardinal points in the center glistening in the light which make the top look a lot more expensive than it is. Make no mistake, Rich has made more intricate top designs, but this is the perfect balance in my opinion. Lots of high end detail work AND a powerful performer (many intricate designs spin for less time due to wind resistance & drag), and that’s why the Navigator is my personal favorite design. I plan to own several variations of this one. Visually impressive, long spinning, and compact size… this may be the perfect BilletSpin design.


In addition to securing your order for this amazing top, your pledge will be used to help keep our men and women working. We make our tops right here in Oshkosh, WI. Each one is assembled, spin tested and packed for shipping by hand. We thank you for joining us and becoming one of the BilletSPIN family!
story_txt:
Hello Indiegogo! It all started right here, so we could think of no better way to celebrate our 25th design than with all of you! It is amazing how much has happened this past year and it is all thanks to you! As promised in our original Kickstarter project, we started our own website, www.billetspin.com and the BilletSPIN Facebook group. We produced 24 new designs, each one sellling out in record time. One of our customers even created a fan website with photos of all our designs! BilletSPIN is now one of the leading names in precision tops. The Kraken became one of the most sought-after tops ever made when it was featured in a famous knife reviewer's YouTube video. Our customer base presently spans the entire world. Accidents happen... It hasn't been all good, though. Our 5-axis Mazak Integrex machine recently experienced a devastating crash. It was a very costly repair and a major blow to our business. BilletSPIN rallied to meet the challenge. Mazak Integrex I-200 during the repair processOur MissionOur passion and principles drive us to create unique, sophisticated designs that look great and perform on the highest level. They have helped us navigate past the difficulties of starting a new business. They have led us to new friends in all corners of the world. That brings us to right here, right now. Our 25th design embodies the same passion and principles that guide us, our company and our fans.Presenting the BilletSPIN Navigator Presenting the BilletSPIN Navigator. The Navigator is a three piece top consisting of an outer collar, inner disc and stem. The contact point is a ceramic bearing ball which is not only durable but precise. By using three pieces, we are able to create stunning material contrasts. The compass themed inner disc and outer collar lends the Navigator its name. Photos courtesy of Jim SkeltonWe wanted the Navigator to be visually stunning and have the performance to match, so we chose our 4 best selling material combinations to bring to Indiegogo. The Navigator is 1.1" in diameter and available in combinations of copper, bronze and stainless steel. For those looking for the longest spinning combination, the SS/Cu/SS averages about 30 seconds extra spin time. Copper is the heaviest of the three materials but also the softest. Stainless Steel is the most durable. Bronze has the most luster, is lighter than copper and is not quite as durable as Stainless Steel.  Additional Standard Material choices!Due to the overwhelming support we are adding two more standard material options. For those of you that chose a perk for more than one top these are eligible to be chosen. They also have their own perk for those that just found the project!


NEW Exotic MaterialsDue to the overwhelming support, we are also adding three exotics materials to the project! YOU CANNOT CHOOSE THESE AS PART OF YOUR MULTIPLE TOP PERK!!! The only way to get them is to pledge on the exotic perks. Shipping is included and you can pledge on multiple perks. This means even if you pledged prior to now you can still pledge for these as well! Due to the extreme costs of these materials the prices are higher and they are all limited quantities!


Whatever combination you choose, the Navigator is easily capable of spin times over ten minutes, as demonstrated in the video below. 
 Amazingly fast stabilization of the NavigatorJim Skelton Testimonial: I just wanted to give a quick testimonial. I own the prototype Navigator (Rich was kind enough to share my photos of it on his campaign), and out of all the BilletSpin Tops that I own, the Navigator is my favorite spinner, hands-down. It has a more compact size in both diameter and stem height than most of the others I own, and that translates to a different feeling when you spin it. It’s much easier to get a stable spin right away, and even when you don’t, it stabilizes faster than any other BilletSpin I own. My average times have been between 9 minutes and 10 minutes on my steel-over-copper version. It’s also a gorgeous design, with the cardinal points in the center glistening in the light which make the top look a lot more expensive than it is. Make no mistake, Rich has made more intricate top designs, but this is the perfect balance in my opinion. Lots of high end detail work AND a powerful performer (many intricate designs spin for less time due to wind resistance & drag), and that’s why the Navigator is my personal favorite design. I plan to own several variations of this one. Visually impressive, long spinning, and compact size… this may be the perfect BilletSpin design.In addition to securing your order for this amazing top, your pledge will be used to help keep our men and women working. We make our tops right here in Oshkosh, WI. Each one is assembled, spin tested and packed for shipping by hand. We thank you for joining us and becoming one of the BilletSPIN family!

story:
My Large Work

To date I have 4 completed large pictures, and another is 80% finished.  It has taken me about 2 months to complete each of the larger works.  I need to finish at least 12 large pieces in order to do a show. 

                         OLD CAR AUCTION, what do ya bid?

 

This piece measures 36 by 35 inches and is titled RED'S ROUTE 66 GIANT HAMBURG.  

 

__________________________________________________________

Thank You Very Much, Phil

story:
...and for every 250 prints you sponsor for your favorite libraries, I'll donate $1000 to the library in my own town.

About the Campaign

So if you've watched my campaign video (and if not, why not?) you know already that I am rich in pixels, but not in much else, and that if I hope to send this pair of archival prints off to about ten of my very favorite libraries then I must convince you to do the same thing for that one library that means the most to you.

If we reach the funding goal for the campaign then I'll be able to send my prints off to those libraries I've loved. I hope we will!

But in fact, that's just where things start.
Because what I really hope is that a whole lot more of you will pile on to do this nice, impractical thing for your libraries and the librarians who work in them; and if I'm right, then we'll raise enough money that I can contribute actual, real cash dollars to the public library in my own small town.

I'd love to send money to everybody's favorite libraries - but by the time we spread those dollars out across the whole lot of them, we'd probably just be buying each library a nice hot latte. That's not to be snorted at, mind you: but I hate to think of all those librarians fighting over that one hot cup of joe. So in this case I figure we're all better off if I act locally, the way the bumper stickers tell us to do.

 About the Prints

There's a right panel, and a left panel, in this set of two prints. Each one measures 20" by 30" (including that blue margin we see all around them) and I've rendered them at 300 pixels to the inch.

As this campaign begins I have rendered out all of the layers and masks I need to complete them, but I haven't yet started my post work in Photoshop. I'd be surprised if that amounted to more than about ten days of uninterrupted work - although it's true that  I do get surprised sometimes. But there shouldn't be any difficulty in finishing the images before the end of this campaign.

There are a couple of areas where now that I've seen the images in their full resolution I may want to go back, rework some details, and re-render those small areas. That's business as usual when I work on this scale.

They'll be printed using an archival photographic process on heavy weight, glossy paper. This is exactly what I do with the other archival prints that I sell through my Retropolis web site. They're really, really nice.

When you sponsor a gift of these prints to your favorite library I'll include a letter to the library that tells them that it was you who sponsored the gift. I'll probably mention what a nice person you are.

What Could Possibly Go Wrong?

You've seen that the pictures are in their final stage, and I've told you about how long it should take me to complete them. You may not know me; but I can point you at a few of my web sites (Retropolis, The Celtic Art Works, and Thrilling Tales of the Downright Unusual) as proof that I'm not new to this kind of work and that I probably know what I'm talking about.

There is a possibility that a client will be bringing me a web site redesign project during the months of November or December, and that could disrupt my schedule. That's the reason why I've launched this campaign before the pictures are done.

Here's another thing, though: these libraries haven't asked for the prints. In most cases they will not know that they're coming. There's no way of knowing what they will choose to do with them. Some may get framed and hung publicly; some may get stuck up in a library's administrative offices, possibly with thumb tacks; some lucky and fast-moving librarians may end up taking them home. We don't know, and in my opinion it doesn't matter. They're gifts! People can do whatever they like with them.

I've posted very conservative shipping dates for the prints (January 20). In fact I hope to ship them sooner but I've found that packing and shipping rewards can take a lot longer than I expect - and anyway I've never placed such a large order with my printer, and I have no idea how long they'll need to produce (I hope!) hundreds of these. So for those reasons, not to mention what shipping is like near the holidays, I'm promising to ship these early next year even though I think they may go out sooner.

Questions that might have been asked frequently if I weren't writing this in advance

1. Wouldn't it be a lot better if we all just gave cash to our own local libraries?

Yep, they need money a lot more than they need prints. If your question is practical (that is, if you've got your checkbook out and you're ready to hand your money over) then by all means, go away and give them money right now. But if your question is theoretical (that is, you're a nitpicker by nature) then you'll just need to sort it out for yourself.

2. Are these contributions tax deductible?

Nope. I'm not a nonprofit, and it's me that's receiving the funds. Even I can't write off the cost of the prints that we send out because there's no way for me to document that the receiving libraries are nonprofits; I think it's often their community organizations that have nonprofit status. The one part of this that is a write-off for me is the cash contribution to my own local library. I need that deduction since otherwise the money that passes through my bank account looks like income.

3. Am I making money from this?

Up to the campaign goal, all of the funding goes toward the prints you sponsor and the prints I send to my ten or so favorite libraries. If we exceed the goal I do stand to make a little money because we're not funding my own prints any more; that's why the excess starts to go to my local library (and my own tax liability). If we sell a godawful lot of prints, I do stand to make some money. I don't mind. But if that bothers you, go back to #1 and get out your checkbook.

4. Is this campaign in any way endorsed by, sponsored by, encouraged by, or does it involve any public library, including my own local library?

Nope. It's just me. Although I'm fond of my local library it has no affiliation with me and if anything goes wrong here, they didn't do it, didn't know about it, and would have been horrified if they even suspected that I might take all your money and run off to Fiji. Which I'm not going to do. I'm just saying that this campaign is entirely the responsibility of me, and no other person or entity.

story:
Our Story

We are an independent production team determined to put on a 3 day event to satisfy all of your senses and leave you in awe!


Carly Tryens and Aron Blue now have 2 art/music shows under their belts and are planning the third, titled 3HREE. The show is being held at 3 Egg Studios on 79 Lorimer St. in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. This show is unique because there are three event-filled opening nights!


Friday, May 6th, 7-12am

Matthew Clark will be creating a metal sculpture LIVE on the sidewalk in front of the building from 7-10.  This is an amazing opportunity to see the process an artist goes through.  His sketches and notes will be on display and there will be a chance to talk to the artist personally about his process after the event.  THEN, inside pedal-steel extraordinaire, Phil Sterk will be performing original music to accompany the fine art and sculptures displayed throughout the studio.


Saturday, May 7th, 7-12am

Matthew Varvil takes the stage at 10pm to perform his shadow theater.  This is an elaborate but short performance and we suggest you arrive early to be sure it is not missed.


Sunday, May 8th, 8-1am

DAVID AMRAM PERFORMS!!  9-12am David Amram takes the stage with his regular band and appearances by his children.  Poetry by Jack Kerouac will be read.  We are absolutely thrilled that David is playing at our show and it is sure to be something to be remembered which is why we will be recording it!  There will be a DVD copies of his performance available after it is mixed and mastered.  This is an incredible chance to see a living legend! We are expecting an overly packed house so get here early!


Every night

Fine art and Sculptures will be displayed by

(Click on Artist's name)

Harry Gold

Al Benkin

Carly Tryens

Hannah Lichtenstein

Matthew Clark &

Andrew Weeks


The Impact


Putting on a show as vast and extraordinary as this costs money.  The money that you donate will go towards paying the musicians, the (overly expensive, thank you NY state) permit to have Matthew Clark create on the sidewalk, food, the production cost of making the recording of David's live performance and hopefully if we exceed our budget pay back the artists who have donated their pieces as gifts to gracious supporters like you!

If we can not make this money in time we will unfortunately have to compensate.  We have a prioritized list of what we are willing to pay for out of our shallow pockets.  For example, of course we will not let a little money stand in the way of having David Amram grace us with his amazing talent and inspiration. 

Your support will make all of this happen.  If everyone could donate $5 who is excited to see a sculpture being made LIVE on a summer night in Williamsburg

or a beautiful pedal steel player who will bring you to tears with his talent

or an original shadow theater performance by an artist raved about in New Orleans

or DAVID AMRAM (come on!)

not to mention all of the incredible art and sculptures on display for all 3 nights then this event could happen smoothly and we will have plenty more to come(we already talking about a possible show in August if this is a success)!


What We Need & What You Get

Indiegogo is our main sourse of fundraising.  We will also be having a dinner party to show a video and explain in person what we are doing and why we need help in hopes of raising some money.  But this is where we expect to get the damage done.  None of this money is going to us.  Even if there is any money made over our budget we have a list of supporters that we would like to thank with a small check.  We are in fact only asking a suggested donation of 20% (which is so small comparatively) of any artwork sold.  That is almost unheard of.  This show must be a success for us to continue bringing you incredible weekends like this. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Every dollar helps but if you are not in a position to help please send this to anyone who you think would be interested.  And mark your calendar for May 6th, 7th and 8th and we'll see you at 79 Lorimer for 3HREE!


Last but definately not least we would like to thank Lele Galer of Galer Estate Vineyard and Winery for graciously donating her amazing locally grown wine.  We are so so thankful for generous people like her who are making this show possible!
